Australian bushfires extinguished
column2: but climate rows rage on=15 Feb 2020 11:08AM=AFP/ga=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australian-bushfires-extinguished--but-climate-rows-rage-on-12437798=" SYDNEY: Australia's "black summer" of devastating bushfires is finally coming to a close
column3: but bitter arguments over how to tackle climate-fuelled disasters are raging on. When firefighters announced this week that all blazes in the hard-hit state of New South Wales were under control for the first time since September
column4: the relief was palpable. In other regions
column5: a few fires are still being contained
column6: but most Australians can finally abandon the grim rituals of the last half-year - morning checks of smog monitors and "Fires Near Me" apps
column7: deciding whether the kids can play outside
column8: whether to flee or defend their homes. But the after-effects will endure
column9: and national soul searching has already begun. "We know events like these can challenge the way we think about the world
column10: undermine our perceptions of safety
column11: and rupture social bonds
column12: said disaster response expert Erin Smith. Dozens of families have lost loved ones, thousands of homes and farms have been gutted, swathes of the east coast are scarred charcoal-black and millions have had their sense of security shaken. It will likely take years and a great deal of imagination for us to figure out where we go from here
column13: said Smith. The question of what is next for Australia is already being asked, most of all of political leaders, and it is being met mostly with finger-pointing and recrimination. HEADS ABOVE THE PARAPET" While scientists agree climate change created favourable conditions for the blazes
column14: politicians of all stripes are acutely aware how sensitive the issue is in Australian politics. In an arid nation whose economic strength is intimately tied to the mining and export of fossil fuels
column15: at least four prime ministers have been ousted in part over their climate policies. In recent weeks
column16: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has seen his ruling conservative coalition threatened by members in rural constituencies demanding funding for more coal-fired power plants. At the same time
column17: the centrist wing of his party has criticised his climate targets as inadequate. Meanwhile rebel members of opposition Labor met secretly to steer the centre-left party's leadership toward a more overtly pro-coal stance. The party's deputy leader awkwardly refused to rule out more coal subsidies
column18: months after vowing they should end. "They don't want to stick their heads above the parapet
column19: at least when it comes to suggesting substantive policy
column20: said Matt McDonald, an expert in climate politics from the University of Queensland. One reason, he explained, is that while the hot and dry Australian continent is uniquely susceptible to the impact of climate change, it is also a world-beating source of coal. Coal accounts for around 75 per cent of Australia's electricity generation and exports of the fossil fuel are worth A$60 billion a year, the country's largest export after iron ore. People in affluent suburbs may call for emissions cuts and green energy, but coal accounts for thousands of jobs in election-deciding districts of Queensland and New South Wales, and many more in the related aluminium smelting business. Independent MP Zali Steggall - a former barrister and Olympic medal-winning skier - who ousted climate-sceptic former prime minister Tony Abbott from his Sydney seat at the last election, wants to take some heat out of the debate. She has introduced a bill that would reduce Australia's carbon emissions to zero by 2050 and divert some contentious issues to an independent expert body. The debate has been very divisive
column21: in part because of the blame game, Steggall told AFP. There was a certain defensiveness in the early days of this debate because the finger was so squarely pointed at coal and fossil fuels." "You have to think about a generation that worked really hard at building Australia's prosperity on fossil fuels. You have to be very careful in the debate about apportioning blame. It's not like it was done on purpose." "It's about recognising and being thankful for that contribution
column22: but acknowledging that we do need to evolve
column23: she added. We're all going to get there in the end." With bushfires projected to get even more deadly and the next season a little over six months away
column24: the risk
column25: Steggall says
column26: is that politicians take so long to reach consensus "it will be too late to do anything"."

column1: Fires contained in hard-hit Australia state
column2: but now floods threaten=13 Feb 2020 05:45PM=AFP/nr=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australia-fires-contained-flood-threat-12431520=" SYDNEY: All the blazes in Australia's hard-hit state of New South Wales have been brought under control
column3: firefighters said on Thursday (Feb 13)
column4: signalling the end of a "black summer" that claimed 33 lives nationwide. But heavy rains that helped extinguish the blazes that have raged along the east coast since September are causing flash floods in parts of the state
column5: posing new problems for some residents. "Not all fires are out
column6: there's still some fire activity in the far south of the state but all fires are contained so we can really focus on helping people rebuild
column7: the state's fire service deputy commissioner Rob Rogers said on Twitter.   It is very good news
column8: a Rural Fire Service spokesman told AFP. Bushfires scorched more than 10 million hectares in the country's east and south, killing at least 33 people and an estimated one billion animals, while destroying more than 2,500 homes. The crisis cloaked major cities including Sydney in smoke for weeks on end, saw towns cut off and prompted the deployment of the military to rescue stranded citizens. Beleaguered volunteer firefighters have fought the blazes day-in-day-out in what has been described as Australia's black summer". The fires were exacerbated by prolonged drought and worsened by climate change in the country's hottest and driest year on record. NOT THREATENING Days of recent rainfall have extinguished the largest fires and brought those that remain under control. In the Australian Capital Territory around Canberra firefighters are still trying to bring one blaze under control
column9: but it was not said to be threatening. Attention has now turned to tackling flash flooding expected in the coming days following the heaviest rains in 30 years. On Thursday dams near Sydney overflowed after days of torrential rain
column10: a spectacular reversal from months of drought. The Nepean dam was just a third full less than a week ago
column11: but on Thursday video footage showing water cascading over the dam wall. Hundreds of people have been rescued from floodwaters in recent days. Wild weather is set to ramp up again from Friday
column12: with the Bureau of Meteorology forecasting ex-Tropical Cyclone Uesi would bring "damaging to destructive winds" and heavy rainfall to remote tourist destination Lord Howe Island. Senior meteorologist Grace Legge said storms were also expected for Queensland and New South Wales -- with areas still recovering from bushfires likely to be hit again. "Any showers and thunderstorms that do develop are falling on already saturated catchments
column13: so there is a risk with severe thunderstorms of flash flooding
column14: she said.

column1: In fire-hit rural Australia
column2: climate debate burns deep=11 Feb 2020 07:28PM (Updated: 11 Feb 2020 07:47PM)=Reuters/jt=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/in-fire-hit-rural-australia--climate-debate-burns-deep-12422084=" BUCHAN
column3: Australia: Returning from a morning feeding his sheep
column4: Jeff McCole
column5: a 70-year-old farmer
column6: paused to take in the bittersweet scene – a few droplets of rain falling onto the remains of his fire-ravaged home. "Nothing like the sound of rain on a tin roof
column7: he said, as he scanned the residue of a lifetime of memories scattered before him. By the old front door was a charred metal toy truck his grandchildren once raced down the verandah. Under the remains of the tin roof, a collection of books, his wife's pride and joy"
column8: had been reduced to layers of feathery ash. And out back
column9: the skeleton of a Valencia orange tree
column10: planted by his mother 65 years ago
column11: was now laden with baubles of charcoaled fruit.   Seasonal bushfires have struck Australia in a way like never before
column12: making for months of monster blazes and toxic haze
column13: and fuelling a polarising debate over climate change. But in Buchan
column14: a conservative-voting farming town in Victoria state that is home to the McCole farm
column15: most locals said they believed the catastrophic fires had nothing to do with global warming. Climate change was "a load of crap"
column16: said McCole
column17: an idea pushed by city folk with "no experience in the bush" and no understanding of Australia's punishing
column18: cyclical climate. "We've had severe droughts and everything like that
column19: 70 years ago
column20: said McCole, a Vietnam war veteran with sky-blue eyes. It just keeps going around in circles. If you wait
column21: it's going to change." RISING RISKS For decades scientists have warned that climate change would increase the risk of extreme bushfires in Australia. This year
column22: there was the perfect storm – record-breaking drought and heat coalescing on tinderbox land. Before rains slowed their spread in recent days
column23: the fires had burned through almost 12 million hectares
column24: destroyed more than 2
column25: 800 homes
column26: and claimed the lives of 33 people. An estimated one billion native animals are also believed to have died. Australia has one of the world's highest carbon footprints per capita and is one of the largest exporters of coal and gas
column27: making successive governments reluctant to adopt climate change policies they say could undermine the economy. But with these unprecedented bushfires
column28: the government has come under increased pressure from environmental groups
column29: scientists and broader swathes of the Australian public to address the climate change issue. "People are more fearful of the future because they glimpsed the future this summer
column30: said Lesley Hughes, a professor and climate scientist at Macquarie University. I think it has been really wounding of the Australian psyche."   Polling by the Australia Institute
column31: a Canberra think tank
column32: in January found that 79 per cent of Australians said they were concerned about climate change
column33: up five percentage points from last July
column34: with 47per cent "very concerned"
column35: a jump of 10 points. But there remains widespread scepticism that the severity of the fires is due to climate change
column36: with many conservative politicians and media suggesting that factors such as arson
column37: the length of cyclical droughts or poor management of flammable vegetation are more responsible. Prime Minister Scott Morrison
column38: who had previously declined to discuss the link between climate change and the fires
column39: recently acknowledged the connection
column40: but said his priority was managing the economic impact. Morrison last week cited "hazard reduction" – which includes the practice of controlled burns to reduce the amount of flammable vegetation in the bush
column41: as a key to mitigating fires in the future
column42: saying it was just as important as reducing emissions. Climate scientists say that the bigger problem for Australia are longer droughts and increasingly hot summers.   The issue of controlled burns is a deeply emotional one in Buchan
column43: where at least 20 homes were lost in the fires that struck in December. "Climate change or not
column44: said Donald Graham, a farmer who survived the fires huddled in his concrete bunker with a stack of cheese and vegemite sandwiches. These fires were a disaster waiting to happen." A DEATH TRAP The road from Melbourne to Buchan winds past a series of small country towns
column45: pie shops and historic churches and
column46: after a weekend of rain
column47: verdant green fields with dairy cows. But closer to Buchan
column48: population 385
column49: the road is eerily burnt out
column50: lined by rows of black tree trunks sticking out of ashy ground. When the bushfires hit the town on Dec. 30
column51: they roared in on three fronts with a ferocity that no locals had ever seen. For more than a month
column52: fires had raged ominously in nearby bushland
column53: finally bellowing in with "one heck of a red glow"
column54: McCole said.   From the verandah of his home
column55: nestled on a 400-hectare property of rolling hills
column56: gum trees and Merino sheep
column57: he watched a giant orange plume crest over the hill and rain down fiery embers. "We only had ten minutes to get out and I think that was the best call I ever made
column58: he said with a wry laugh. It was a death trap." The town of Buchan is a single main street with a general store and a pub - the kind of place where locals have time to discuss the pressing issues of the day with a stranger. "The issue of climate change and the fire is a dead duck as far as I'm concerned
column59: said Graham, an animated 68-year-old cattleman with a shock of gray hair. What is the most significant thing
column60: is the changing structure of the forest." Minutes before he watched his house go up in flames from the peephole of his bunker
column61: Graham raced inside to grab a picture from the wall
column62: a colonial lithograph featuring the magnificent valley below overlooking the confluence of the Snowy and Buchan rivers.   The picture is significant because it shows how much the land has changed
column63: he said. "We've got an accumulation of vegetation. Our area was burned 50 to 70 years ago and it has not burned since
column64: and at some point it will burn
column65: he said. It just needs a few things to come together
column66: a few dry years and some lightning and neither of those are peculiar to the Australian landscape." His neighbour John Coates
column67: a 76-year-old cattle farmer
column68: said that decades of vegetation growth had turned the land into a "timebomb". Walking through their property overlooking the Snowy River National Park
column69: Coates and his wife Janice shook their heads at the destruction – bald
column70: blackened hills and the devastated gorge below
column71: once filled with ferns
column72: lyrebirds and platypus in the creek. Many locals in Buchan recall the days they would carry a box of matches in their pockets so they could carry out their own hazard-reduction burns. But regulations subsequently put in place aimed at protecting state forests and bushland mean they are now dependent on government agencies for carrying out controlled burns. For years
column73: local farmers had urged the government to carry out burns to reduce the "fuel load"
column74: or the accumulation of trees
column75: underbrush and dry grass that can turn a small bushfire into an inferno
column76: Coates said. But it never happened.   Chris Hardman
column77: the chief fire officer for Forest Fire Management Victoria
column78: said in a statement to Reuters that his agency had planned to burn 246
column79: 396 hectares of the state's public land last year
column80: but was "unable to do so because it would have been unsafe". Scientists also say the drought and increasingly hot weather means there are fewer days that vegetation can be safely burned. Commenting on the issue in New South Wales
column81: Richie Merzian
column82: climate and energy program director at the Australia Institute
column83: said it was not a case of failing to implement techniques that had worked in the past
column84: but that such techniques were "insufficient to address the scenario now". "You can't blame the dry conditions and say it has no relevance to climate change
column85: he said. It's a combination of many different climatic changes that can be linked back to the overall trend." SEASONS 'OUT OF SYNC' In Buchan
column86: not everyone in town was averse to talk of climate change – a few spoke of the seasons being "out of sync"
column87: the lack of rain or the demise of fragrant yellow box flowers in the valley. But the fires have mainly reinforced pre-existing views and gripes
column88: reflecting the polarising rhetoric of the national climate change debate. Last November
column89: Australia's Deputy Prime Minister Michael McCormack – who heads the party that won in the electorate that includes Buchan – described climate change concerns as those held by "inner-city raving lunatics".   That messaging appeared to resonate in Buchan
column90: far from the skyscrapers and the lights of Melbourne or Sydney
column91: with a strong sense that people here were living far greener lives. "They blame our cows
column92: said McCole, referring to recent attention on the earth-warming methane produced by belching or flatulent cattle. But, he said, they are all jumping on electric trains and cars and god knows what in the city and there are millions of them
column93: flying around the world in jumbo jets." "It takes a good cow to put out that many emissions
column94: he said. I can tell ya.""

column1: Rains forecast to douse Australia wildfires
column2: raising hopes crisis nearly over=11 Feb 2020 06:49PM=Reuters/jt=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/rains-forecast-to-douse-australia-wildfires--raising-hopes-crisis-nearly-over-12423196=" SYDNEY: Torrential rain across Australia's east could extinguish all remaining bushfires in the country's most populous state by the end of the week
column3: authorities said on Tuesday (Feb 11)
column4: raising hopes a deadly national crisis is almost over. Australia has been battling hundreds of blazes since September in an unusually prolonged summer wildfire season that was fuelled by three years of drought
column5: which experts have attributed to climate change. Heavy rain and storms have in recent days swept across New South Wales (NSW) state
column6: which bore the brunt of a crisis that engulfed several states and territories at its peak. The downpour has already doused two of the biggest and longest running blazes and NSW officials are hopeful that more rain forecast for this week will extinguish the remaining 24 fires
column7: four of which are burning "uncontrolled".   "All going well
column8: all will be contained and we're hopeful to get to a stage where we can call them out
column9: the NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) said in an emailed statement. The current situation is a far cry from the height of the crisis in early January when NSW firefighters were battling almost 150 fires that produced a firefront about 6,000km long. Blazes across the country have razed nearly 12 million hectares of tinder-dry bushland, killing 33 people and an estimated 1 billion native animals, since September. The fires destroyed thousands of homes and prompted mass evacuations of both locals and tourists under apocalyptic-like red skies during Australia's peak summer holiday period.   Hawkesbury City Mayor Barry Calvert said the dousing of the massive Gospers Mountain fire this week was a huge relief. We've been living with this fire for four months
column10: he told Reuters by telephone. We could never relax. For several weeks
column11: we all had our bags packed ready to evacuate as the fire would move quickly in different directions depending on how the wind changed." "The smoke would also get you down
column12: we were desperate for some clean air." WELCOME SURPRISE The welcome rainfall has come as something of an early surprise. The Bureau of Meteorology in January said rains sufficient enough to extinguish the fires was unlikely until at least March. In neighbouring Victoria state
column13: firefighters were battling around 20 blazes on Tuesday - down from a peak of 60. Heavy rain was also forecast in Victoria for coming days
column14: although officials expect it to dampen
column15: rather than extinguish
column16: many of the fires. "The lower end rainfall totals won't put out fires
column17: they will allow them to be contained or controlled by firefighters in the near future
column18: Victorian State Response Controller Tim Wiebusch told reporters in Melbourne.   In Queensland state, which also received heavy rainfalls, just one fire remains ablaze, while nine fires are alight in South Australia south. The rainfall has, however, proved to be a double-edged sword. Nearly 60,000 households across NSW remained without electricity on Tuesday as flash flooding bought down powerlines and trees.

column1: Floods fail to end Australia's years-long drought=11 Feb 2020 05:59PM=AFP/nc=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australia-bushfire-drought-floods-weather-12422950=" SYDNEY: Heavy rain has given hope to Australia's drought-stricken regions
column2: but scientists warned Tuesday (Feb 11) sustained falls were needed to end a years-long dry spell. Stormy weather has brought days of chaos and destruction in the country's east
column3: with one man missing after his car was swept off a road in Sydney's north and hundreds more rescued from floodwaters. In the small town of Stanthorpe
column4: Queensland
column5: Tracy Dobie said the rain had been "a boost for everyone". "But the drought has not ended
column6: the regional mayor told AFP. Our land is so dehydrated - we've gone three years without rain in some places and five years in others - it's going to take a long time to get moisture back in the soil." Hydrologists believe this week's deluge - which has caused flooding and doused many fires - is a taste of things to come
column7: with cities getting inundated while rural areas struggle to offset worsening droughts. Professor Ashish Sharma from the University of New South Wales said heavy rain can give people in cities a "twisted view" of the impact
column8: as water builds up on hard surfaces. Even as people in cities see flooding and property damage
column9: in rural regions sustained rainfall is needed to soak through the dry soil before dams fill. During the latest downpours - the heaviest in 30 years in some areas - dam levels near Sydney have risen dramatically. But most of New South Wales' drought-hit towns facing down a water "Day Zero" had seen "negligible" increases
column10: as much of the rain was flowing into rivers not dams
column11: said a spokesman for WaterNSW
column12: which manages the state's water resources. "Unfortunately (that is) largely because the volume hasn't been sufficient and the catchments are extremely dry after a very hot start to the summer and a prolonged drought
column13: he said. Despite climate change driving increases in extreme rainfall, Sharma and his team predict it will not be enough to keep up with rising temperatures. Moderate and frequent floods, which form the backbone of all our water supply"
column14: will likely decrease
column15: Sharma said. "I just hope that people have the wisdom and the foresight to realise that this should not be seen as a sign of not needing to act
column16: he added. Dobie said the rain was more than welcome but one rain event doesn't close the door on the drought". "We need a year of average rainfall.""

column1: Downpours to end Australia bushfires within days=10 Feb 2020 04:10PM (Updated: 10 Feb 2020 04:13PM)=AFP=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australia-bushfires-end-rain-12417138=" SYDNEY: Australia's months-long bushfire crisis will likely be over within days
column2: officials said Monday (Feb 10) as heavy rainfall extinguished several massive blazes and was forecast to douse dozens more as downpours swept south. Days of torrential rains have caused flash flooding in New South Wales and Queensland
column3: dampening once-raging fires that volunteers had battled in vain for months. Sydney experienced its wettest period in 20 years amid several days of heavy rainfall that led to chaotic scenes across the city. The Bureau of Meteorology said 391.6mm (15.42 inches) of rain fell in Sydney over the past four days - the highest total in such a period since 414.2mm were recorded in February 1990. Several major bushfires have been extinguished by the deluge
column4: including a "mega-blaze" that burned through 500
column5: 000 hectares (1.2 million acres) north of Sydney and a similar-sized fire to the city's south
column6: bringing relief to residents and firefighters. New South Wales Rural Fire Service spokesman James Morris said about 30 fires were still burning Monday
column7: but it was expected they would soon be extinguished as the rain moves south in the coming days. "By the end of the week it's likely they will be out
column8: he told AFP. Drought-stricken areas across the country's east also received welcome downpours but more sustained and widespread rainfall will be needed to offset a years-long dry spell. The stormy weather has brought days of chaos and destruction, with one man missing after his car was swept off a road in Sydney's north and hundreds more rescued from floodwaters across the state. Police said a search was under way for the missing man Monday but no sign of him or his vehicle had been found. Several rivers, including the Parramatta River in Sydney's west, overflowed while residents living near Narrabeen Lagoon in the city's north were ordered to evacuate late Sunday amid fears their homes could be inundated. Emergency services scrambled to respond to calls for assistance as strong winds uprooted trees, ocean foam coated seaside homes and boulders fell on parked cars. Almost 90,000 homes remained without power Monday, with utility providers warning it could take days for electricity to be restored in some areas. The Insurance Council of Australia said insurers had received an estimated A$45 million (US$30 million) in claims by early Monday, with that figure expected to rise as the full extent of the damage becomes clear.

column1: Heavy rain douses Australia's east coast bushfires=10 Feb 2020 07:14AM=Reuters/de=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/heavy-rain-douses-australia-s-east-coast-bushfires-12415264=" MELBOURNE: Australian authorities issued evacuation orders as heavy rain lashed Sydney and the east coast of the state of New South Wales (NSW) on Monday (Feb 10)
column2: bringing chaos to the country's largest city while dousing bushfires that have raged since November. Between 200 and 400 millimetres of rain drenched the Sydney area out to the Blue Mountains and farther south over the weekend
column3: the Bureau of Meteorology said
column4: which led to rivers flooding and forced more than 60 schools to shut on Monday. The NSW State Emergency Service received over 2
column5: 700 calls for help overnight
column6: with the number of calls since last Wednesday topping 10
column8: SES spokesman Andrew Richards said. "It's certainly quite a significant event. It's led to a record number of calls to our call centre. It's quite widespread
column9: NSW State Emergency Service (SES) spokesman Andrew Richards said. Couple that with gale-force winds off the coast
column10: large six-metre waves
column11: the coastline's getting pretty hammered as well with the high tides and king tides." The Bureau of Meteorology warned that heavy rain could lead to life-threatening flash flooding for the south coast of New South Wales and also said there could be wind gusts of more than 90 kilometres per hour. Thanks to the rain
column12: the NSW Rural Fire Service on Sunday night declared that one of the state's worst bushfires
column13: Currawon on the south coast
column14: was finally out. The fire had burned for 74 days
column15: destroying 312 homes and razing nearly 500
column16: 000 hectares of land. There were still 33 fires burning as of Monday morning in the state
column17: but they were all at the lowest warning level of "advice" and mostly in southeastern areas where the rains were headed. Farmers welcomed the rain but said the water was not going deep enough into the ground to end three years of drought. "It's a really good start to the year. Unfortunately
column18: it's not drought-breaking
column19: Nigel Cornish, a Queensland farmer who is a director of industry group Grain Growers, told Australian Broadcasting Corp radio. The drought has contributed to a horrific fire season that has killed 33 people and an estimated one billion native animals, destroyed more than 2,500 homes and burned more than 11.7 million hectares of land since September.

column1: Bushfires
column2: cyclone
column3: torrential rain hit Australia's coasts=09 Feb 2020 03:39PM=Reuters/nc=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australia-cyclone-weather-bushfire-flooding-12412422=" MELBOURNE: Severe bushfires burned through parts of Western Australia on Sunday (Feb 9)
column4: with other areas of the state dealing with the aftermath of a powerful cyclone
column5: while the country's east coast was facing potential life-threatening flash flooding. After months of destructive wildfires that have razed millions of hectares of land
column6: Australia has been hit in recent weeks by wild weather that has alternately brought heavy downpours
column7: hail storms
column8: gusty winds and hot and dry air. About a dozen fires were burning in Western Australia (WA) on Sunday
column9: with severe fire danger expected in several districts
column10: according to fire services and the state's Bureau of Meteorology. Daytime temperatures in some of the districts were forecast at up to 42 degrees Celsius. The state's upper parts were battling on Sunday the aftermath of a tropical cyclone Damien that made a landfall on Saturday afternoon
column11: bringing gusty winds of up to 200kph.   No immediate damages were reported and the cyclone was expected to weaken as it moved inland
column12: but winds were seen to blow at more than 100kph. "Although Tropical #CycloneDamien has weakened significantly from the thrashing it gave Karratha and Dampier yesterday
column13: areas around Tom Price and Paraburdoo are receiving significant rainfall and squally conditions
column14: the state's Bureau of Meteorology said on its Twitter account. On the opposite coast of Australia, Sydney and the state of New South Wales were in danger of potential life-threatening flash flooding as rain kept bucketing down for a third day in a row in downpours not seen since 1998. Rainfall in some parts of the state approached half the annual average, but the falls were welcomed after the state saw its driest year on record in 2019, at 55 per cent below average. The state's Bureau of Meteorology said there was potential for heavy rainfall and life-threatening flash-flooding
column15: and coast erosion, although little danger of river flooding as water levels have been low due to a persistent drought. In Queensland, meteorologists also warned of flash and riverine flooding on Sunday, following heavy falls overnight. An emergency flood alert was issued for residents of Dalby due to a creek overflowing, about 200km west of Brisbane.

column1: Torrential rain now affecting sports in Australia=08 Feb 2020 01:45PM=Reuters=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/sport/torrential-rain-now-affecting-sports-in-australia-12410600=" SYDNEY: Torrential rain has forced the postponement of an A-League derby match in Sydney on Saturday
column2: continuing the run of sports events affected by adverse weather conditions in Australia. The clash between the league-leading Sydney FC and Western Sydney Wanderers had been scheduled to be held at Kograh Oval on Saturday evening. Football Federation Australia (FFA) officials
column3: however
column4: postponed the match after an inspection of the venue earlier on Saturday and in consultation with the clubs and broadcasters. "With over 100 millimetres of rain falling in the Sydney area over the past two days
column5: and in the interest of player welfare
column6: all parties agreed that it was not possible to play the match as scheduled
column7: FFA Head of Leagues Greg O'Rourke said. Whilst it is disappointing that a nearly sold-out crowd is unable to see another iconic Sydney derby today
column8: this was the right decision." FFA said the match would be rescheduled following discussions with the clubs and broadcasters. The soccer clash was not the only top-level sport affected on Saturday
column9: with the final of the domestic Twenty20 Big Bash cricket league between the Sydney Sixers and Melbourne Stars also in jeopardy. Australian sports events have been badly affected by adverse weather in the last few months
column10: principally due to bushfires. A Big Bash match in Canberra was abandoned in December due to bushfire smoke
column11: while players attempting to qualify for the Australian Open tennis Grand Slam in Melbourne in early January complained of not being able to breathe properly. The fires
column12: however
column13: have actually been doused in the last 24 hours by the biggest rainfall in almost 20 years
column14: while Western Australia is also bracing for a lashing from severe tropical cyclone Damien. (Reporting by Greg Stutchbury in Wellington; Editing by Kenneth Maxwell)"

column1: Australia welcomes drought-easing drenching
column2: even as it brings floods=07 Feb 2020 06:42AM=Reuters/de=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australia-welcomes-drought-easing-drenching--even-as-it-brings-floods-12403292=" SYDNEY: The east coast of Australia welcomed the heaviest drenching in years on Friday (Feb 7)
column3: dousing some of the country's most damaging and long-running wildfires and easing a drought that has crippled farming across two states. Sydney alone had seen more than 60 millimetres of rain in the past 24 hours and was forecast to receive up to 360 millimetres more by Monday. column1: Joker's Joaquin Phoenix takes aim at climate apathy with film about dying Earth=07 Feb 2020 12:00AM (Updated: 07 Feb 2020 07:41AM)=Reuters/sr=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/lifestyle/joker-joaquin-phoenix-climate-change-film-guardians-of-life-12402380=" Oscar favourite Joaquin Phoenix stars as a medic battling to save a dying planet Earth in a film launched on Thursday (Feb 6)
column2: the first in a series of short Hollywood productions aimed at spurring action on climate change. The Joker star teamed up with environmental activist group Extinction Rebellion and Amazon Watch
column3: a California-based organisation campaigning to protect the Amazon rainforest
column4: to produce the two-minute film Guardians Of Life. Shot in a Los Angeles emergency room
column5: the movie shows doctors attempting to save an unidentified patient whose flatlining vital signs represent the threat posed by climate change
column6: deforestation and fires from Australia to the Amazon. "It's really a call to action
column7: said Phoenix, among the most prominent Hollywood stars to draw attention to the catastrophic damage being caused by human-induced global warming. People don't realise there's still time
column8: but only if we act now and make sweeping changes to our consumption. We can't wait for governments to solve these problems for us." Founded in Britain
column9: Extinction Rebellion promotes its climate activism through civil disobedience
column10: and Phoenix was himself arrested at a climate change protest organised by fellow Hollywood star Jane Fonda in Washington last month
column11: a few days after winning a Golden Globe for his starring role in Joker. The first in a planned series of 12 short films
column12: Guardians Of Life points to the vital role indigenous people play in protecting habitats
column13: a finding emphasised by scientists studying the million plant and animal species they say risk extinction due to damage caused by industrial society. "This film is very important for us at this moment
column14: said Sonia Guajajara, head of Brazil's largest indigenous umbrella organisation, the Association of Indigenous Peoples. It demonstrates the artists' engagement in Amazon protection by showing the key role indigenous peoples play in defending the forests
column15: the planet
column16: and life itself." Rosario Dawson
column17: Matthew Modine and Oona Chaplin appear alongside Phoenix in the film. It was directed by Shaun Monson and produced with Mobilize Earth
column18: a US not-for-profit organisation set up for the series
column19: and aims to raise money for Extinction Rebellion and Amazon Watch. "There is still a disconnect between how bad things are and the action that needs to happen
column20: said Gail Bradbrook, a co-founder of Extinction Rebellion. But that gap is narrowing. There are more significant people starting to break ranks
column21: to tell the truth and act as if it is real." (Source: Reuters)"

column1: Heatwave and high winds threaten to rekindle Australian wildfires=30 Jan 2020 09:55AM (Updated: 30 Jan 2020 04:50PM)=Reuters/nc/ec=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australia-bushfires-threat-forecast-heat-12369004=" SYDNEY: Large swathes of southeast Australia were bracing on Thursday (Jan 30) for a days-long heatwave that threatens to stoke bushfires that have been burning for months. As firefighters and residents prepared for the heightened danger
column2: the New South Wales (NSW) state government launched a six-month inquiry to examine both the causes of and response to this season's deadly wildfires. "We don't want to waste the opportunity to take on board any recommendations we need to adopt ahead of the bushfire season this year ... as we approach summer of 2021
column3: said Gladys Berejiklian, the premier of NSW. NSW state has been one of the hardest hit by bushfires, which started earlier than usual in September. The blazes have burnt out more than 11.7 million hectares (117,000 sq kms) across Australia's most populous states, killing at least 33 people and about 1 billion animals, and destroying 2,500 homes. Fire danger warnings were issued on Thursday for several areas in South Australia state, where temperatures were forecast to exceed 40 Celsius (104 Fahrenheit) and winds were expected to reach 35km (22 miles) per hour. Among them was Kangaroo Island, a popular tourist destination that has already been razed by fires that killed two people. The severe heat and high winds are forecast to hit NSW and Victoria states from Friday threatening to spark new life into some of the 120 fires burning across the three states or create new blazes. Australia's dangerous summer weather has largely been driven by temperature variations in the Indian Ocean, which the country's weather bureau said on Thursday were likely to keep conditions hot and dry until March. Martin Webster, a NSW Rural Fire Service officer, highlighted the strains facing the state's 74,000-strong volunteer brigade as the huge fires continued to burn. Our local crews have been actively involved in firefighting since August and we are still long way from being out of the woods
column4: so we are talking six or seven months of firefighting
column5: Webster told the Australian Broadcasting Corp.

I will keep that promise if it happens. "Four million Australian dollars would be nice. But there's people that need it... for rebuilding the lives they once knew. "It is much more important that they get that money

Fires have ravaged large parts of Australia, leaving 33 people dead and thousands of homes destroyed, with sports stars around the world rallying to support recovery efforts. It was feared that smoke from the blazes could impact the opening Grand Slam of the year after qualifying was hit by thick smog. But rain helped douse some of the fires and the air quality in Melbourne has not affected the tournament. For Zverev to make good on his pledge he will need to first get past either world number one Rafael Nadal or fifth seed Dominic Thiem in the semi-finals. If he can do that, seven-time champion Novak Djokovic or six-time winner Roger Federer await in the final. Zverev's run to the last four in Melbourne is the farthest he has got in the 19 Grand Slams he has played.

Meteorologists warned on Monday, however, that the cooler conditions may be over. The reprieve may be short lived with a blast of heat likely late this week in some areas

column1: Golf: Herbert wins Dubai Desert Classic in play-off=27 Jan 2020 02:26AM=AFP/de=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/sport/golf-herbert-wins-dubai-desert-classic-in-play-off-12351900=" DUBAI: Lucas Herbert celebrated Australia Day with his first title on the European Tour when he beat South Africa's Christiaan Bezuidenhout to win the Dubai Desert Classic on the second play-off hole on Sunday (Jan 26). After hitting his second shot on the first extra hole into the water on the par-5 18th hole
column2: Herbert made a terrific up-and-down for par to halve the hole
column3: and then birdied the same hole a little while later. Bezuidenhout overshot the green with his second and failed to make his up-and-down from there. For Herbert
column4: it was the biggest final-round comeback in the 31-year history of the tournament after he had started the day five shots behind overnight leader Wu Ashun of China. The previous record was held by Tiger Woods who overcame a four-shot deficit in 2008. Both Bezuidenhout and Herbert shot rounds of four-under par 68 in extremely difficult conditions at the Majlis course of Emirates Golf Club and set the clubhouse marker at nine-under par 279. However
column5: none of the leading players after the third round could catch up with the two as gusting winds of 30 miles per hour and more wreaked havoc. Three players -? Dean Burmester of South Africa (72)
column6: Tom Lewis of England (74) and Adri Arnaus of Spain (70) ?- were tied third at seven-under par 281. It was the 24-year-old Herbert's 50th appearance on the European Tour and the win is expected to lift him from 223rd in the world rankings to number 77 on Monday. 'PRETTY COOL RUSH' "It feels pretty good. I finished top-10 quite a few times and that was a pretty cool rush
column7: but to win is something else
column8: said Herbert, who had started the day with a bogey. Just the fact that with everything that's gone on back home (the country's devastating bush fires)
column9: if I can bring a little bit of joy to the guys who are struggling back there
column10: yeah
column11: it's real special." The 68s by Herbert and Bezuidenhout were the best round of the day as only three holes played below their par score. "It was brutal out there. That rough was up pretty thick. Those greens were baked. That little bit of rain on the back nine kind of helped
column12: because otherwise
column13: those greens were a lot to deal with
column14: added Herbert. Bezuidenhout was handling the tough conditions extremely well and was bogey-free with five birdies in 17 holes, before making his first and only mistake on the last. After laying up perfectly with his second shot on the par-5 18th, he spun back his wedge third into the water and needed to make a putt from 18 feet to avoid a double bogey. On the other hand, Herbert birdied the 17th after hitting his driver to the green edge on the par-4 hole and then smashed his second shot on to the green on the 18th and two-putted from a long range for another birdie to join Bezuidenhout as the clubhouse leader at nine-under par. Defending champion Bryson DeChambeau, of the USA, was in the mix as he reached the 15th tee at nine-under par. He then proceeded to make four bogeys over the closing stretch to drop down to tied eighth position. Overnight leader Wu carded a final round 77 to finish three behind.

column1: Golf: Herbert celebrates Australia Day with maiden title in Dubai==Reuters=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/sport/golf--herbert-celebrates-australia-day-with-maiden-title-in-dubai-12351862=" REUTERS: Lucas Herbert marked Australia Day in his native country by claiming his maiden European Tour title after beating Christiaan Bezuidenhout in a thrilling playoff at the Dubai Desert Classic on Sunday. Herbert saved par on the first extra hole after hitting his approach shot into the water
column2: before returning to the same green to roll in the winning birdie. Earlier
column3: Bezuidenhout and Herbert had finished with final rounds of four-under-par 68 as they emerged from way back in the field to finish nine-under overall - two shots clear of England's Tom Lewis
column4: South African Dean Burmester and Spaniard Adri Arnaus. South African Bezuidenhout found the water on the final hole but recovered with a clutch putt for bogey
column5: while Herbert came home with back-to-back birdies. Last year's champion Bryson DeChambeau grabbed a share of the lead with a birdie on the 13th but fell away in windy conditions
column6: finishing with four straight bogeys in a 76. Overnight leader Wu Ashun of China took sixth spot alongside American Kurt Kitayama at six under
column7: finishing a shot ahead of Frenchman Mike Lorenzo-Vera
column8: Scot Robert MacIntyre and DeChambeau. But the day belonged to Herbert
column9: whose victory in his 50th European Tour appearance will move him back into the top 100 of the world rankings. "It's the best thing ever
column10: it's so good
column11: the 24-year-old said. We've got a bottle of scotch at home to celebrate back in Australia so I can't wait to get into that with the boys." Herbert dedicated his win to those affected by the bushfires in Australia in recent months. "There's some pretty awful stuff happening in Australia right now with the fires... everyone around the world is behind us and hopefully we can keep fighting harder than what I did on that first play-off hole
column12: he added. That's nothing compared to the firefighters and volunteers that are putting out the fires so I'm sending all my love back home." (Reporting by Hardik Vyas in Bengaluru; editing by Clare Fallon)"

column1: Kangaroo Island is an ecological wonderland; now half of it is burnt and survival hangs in the balance==CNA/jb=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/kangaroo-island-australia-bushfires-ecology-survival-12323578=" KANGAROO ISLAND
column2: Australia: The west end of Kangaroo Island could be another planet. Up to the horizon
column3: a moonscape stretches out
column4: scarred by fire and devoid of life. Strong gusts are hurling white sand and ash across empty roads. There is no sound but the rough howl of the wind. It is a sad oddity in a place normally echoing with song and pulsating with colour. It has been left in a monotone state. The Australian bush is as resilient as landscapes come. And this island has been a refuge
column5: to delicate and unique wildlife and to its people.   But these bushfires have cut Kangaroo Island in half. More than 210
column6: 000 hectares have been burnt
column7: including some of its most pristine wilderness. Dozens of homes have succumbed to the flames
column8: roads remain cut
column9: tourists are gone and summer is not over. Survival is everything now. That struggle is playing out hour after hour at Kangaroo Island Wildlife Park
column10: the makeshift centre for emergency animal care in the charred bush. Its owner Sam Mitchell thought he could handle about 15 more koalas in addition to the ones he already kept. “And now we’ve seen over 400
column11: ” he said.   “We weren’t prepared for it but no one was. We’ve just been going flat out for two weeks and we’ve saved a lot of animals. But it’s not just going to blow over. This will be with us for a long time.” Meantime
column12: animal rescuers have documented finding charred corpses of animals every few metres as they traipsed across a smouldering fireground in search of survivors. The death toll is horrendous.  Those they came across were typically in a desperate state. Now
column13: here is an urgent plea for volunteers to fly to the island to provide food
column14: water and basic care to the animals left out there. Species that exist here and nowhere else on the planet are high on the priority list.   There are only 4
column15: 700 people living on Kangaroo Island. Wave after wave of this crisis has fallen over them over the past few weeks. Fatigue is every local’s companion by this point. And still they fear more is to come. The island’s economy is strongly tilted towards agriculture and tourism. With damage done to infrastructure and reputation
column16: both industries face long recoveries. “We could be facing economic collapse if we don’t have people coming through our doors and supporting us. Then people will be letting staff go. And when staff go
column17: they pack up
column18: they leave
column19: they take their skills with them
column20: ” said Leeza Irwin
column21: the co-owner of Raptor Domain
column22: a tourist and educational facility showcasing rescued birds of prey and reptiles.   “The things that Kangaroo Island are known for are still here. But for it to be still here
column23: we need everybody to come and see us and we need them to support us
column24: ” she said. Jim Geddes returned to see his accommodation buildings at Hanson Bay
column25: overlooking a postcard beach
column26: completely destroyed. At his adjoining wildlife sanctuary
column27: a mass grave holds the bodies of some 800 dead animals. But he is still leaning on small pieces of wonder among the devastation. “We still have 30 to 40 koalas
column28: which are completely unscathed and untouched
column29: sort of living just like they always had
column30: ” he said. “I just wish they could tell me where they sheltered during the storm. It’s just a miracle of nature.   “This has been a really tough time but the Australian bush bounces back really
column31: really quickly. There are plenty of green shoots.” The community’s bond has found new strengths during this saga. Out of love for one another and out of necessity. The Western Districts Football Club was known as the “club in the scrub” before the fires surrounded their ground and facilities. As their flag blows in the billowing wind
column32: there is little around them but blackened skeletons of that iconic bushland.   The clubhouse is gone but the support remains. The footy team’s changing rooms have become an emergency hub supporting locals who have lost plenty. “The devastation that has come to the island was just unbelievable
column34: who is managing the hub. “It’s just been a great place for people to come to
column35: for their wellbeing too
column36: just to be able to offload and talk about how things are going
column37: to receive the support that they so desperately need. “People need to rebuild their lives. They’ve lost everything. There are so many that have not only lost their home
column38: they’ve lost their job. Yeah
column39: it’s tough.”   Amid the cooperation
column40: in the shadows division ripples as frustrations grow and blame gets directed. These are hot times
column41: in emotion and in temperature. In 2019
column42: South Australia experienced its driest year on record - 65 per cent less rain than average. Starving for water
column43: the island became a tinderbox. But even the town’s mayor won’t say climate change is at play here. He doesn’t believe in it - and even former US President Barack Obama felt Michael Pengilly’s social media scorn for daring to suggest so. “Pathetic
column44: ” he tweeted.  More green shoots will surely arrive soon. Not soon enough for an island parched of much that it needs to survive."

column1: Bodies of US firefighters retrieved from crash site in Australia=25 Jan 2020 10:04AM=Reuters=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/bodies-of-us-firefighters-retrieved-from-crash-site-in-australia-12330692=" MELBOURNE: The bodies of three US firefighters who died in a plane crash earlier this week in Australia's remote bushland while battling a fierce wildfire have been recovered

column7: of Great Falls

column13: and Flight Engineer Rick DeMorgan Jr
column15: of Navarre

The crash of the C-130 tanker plane on Thursday added to national grief in Australia over bushfires that have since October killed 33 people and millions of animals as well as charred vast swaths of land. Officials said it was too early to speculate on the cause of the crash of the plane that went down just after it dumped a large load of retardant on a huge wildfire in a national park in the mountains south of Canberra
column17: the Australian capital. The Americans were a part of a multi-national contingency that has been helping Australia to combat the devastating bushfires that have in three months scorched a land area about one-third the size of Germany

column1: Australia mourns US firefighters as probe into plane crash begins==Reuters/nr=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australia-mourns-us-firefighters-as-probe-into-plane-crash-12318292=" MELBOURNE: Firefighters in Australia held a minute's silence on Friday (Jan 24) for three US colleagues killed in a plane crash as investigators began scouring the accident site in remote bushland. The premier of New South Wales (NSW) state
column2: where the C-130 Hercules crashed while on a mission to dump retardant on a huge wildfire
column3: ordered that flags on official buildings be flown at half-mast as a mark of respect. "We will forever be indebted to the enormous contribution and indeed the ultimate sacrifice that's been paid as a result of these extraordinary individuals doing a remarkable job
column4: NSW Rural Fire Service Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons said at a farewell near Sydney airport for 32 US firefighters who were returning home after weeks on duty on Australia. Fitzsimmons and air safety officials said it was too early to speculate on the cause of the crash. We simply don't know the circumstances pertaining to the accident at this stage
column5: Fitzsimmons said. Appropriate
column6: formal investigations and inquiries are underway." The three crew who died were Ian McBeth
column8: Paul Hudson
column10: and Rick DeMorgan Jr
column12: their employer
column13: Canadian firm Coulson Aviation said in a statement. All three had previously worked for the US military. Two were married and two left behind young children. "We honour the amazing crews who do incredible things in dangerous circumstances supported by world-class operations
column14: Coulson Aviation said in a statement. The company had grounded its other air tankers in Australia immediately after the crash on Thursday but said they would be returning to work in the very near future". Fitzsimmons earlier said field reports showed there had been a "pretty significant fireball associated with the plane crash"
column15: while a spokesman for Australia's Civil Aviation Safety Authority told Reuters the aircraft went into a valley to drop the retardant and did not emerge. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau said it would provide a preliminary report in about 30 days
column16: after analysing available recorded data
column17: reviewing weather information and interviewing any witnesses. The owner of the aircraft
column18: Canadian aerial firefighting company Coulson Aviation
column19: was sending a team to help with the investigation. They are due to arrive in Sydney on Saturday morning
column20: Fitzsimmons said. A US National Transportation Safety Board official said the agency plans to have some involvement and will likely send an investigator or two to Australia. There have been two previous crashes involving C-130 Hercules aircraft while fighting wildfires. In a 2002 accident in California
column21: caught on video tape
column22: the wings of the plane folded upward
column23: breaking off the plane before the fuselage rolled and hit the ground upside down
column24: killing all three crew. In 2012
column25: another C-130 crashed in South Dakota
column26: killing four of the six crew
column27: in an accident that was later determined to be weather-related. "Unfortunately
column28: aircraft are one of the riskiest parts of wildland firefighting
column29: said Eric Kennedy, a disaster and emergency management expert at York University in California. Kennedy said there many possible causes for Thursday's crash, but noted that a well-known risk in the C-130 fleet was metal fatigue-induced wing failure. Reduced visibility
column30: high turbulence
column31: and low flying can all be contributing risk factors for air tanker crashes
column32: Kennedy said in emailed comments. SMOKE HAZE RETURNS The plane crash on Thursday took the death toll for Australia's devastating bushfire season to 32, including eight firefighters. The wildfires have also killed millions of animals, razed thousands of homes and destroyed a land area about one-third the size of Germany since September. Six local volunteer firefighters were injured later on Thursday when a water tanker vehicle rolled when they were battling a blaze in the south coast region of the state. Three were released from hospital on Thursday night, while the other three would be released on Friday, officials said. While fire conditions eased in southeastern Australia on Friday, Sydney was choking on a new smoke haze, blown in by a baking hot wind from the fires burning in the south of the state. The harbourside city was also covered in a layer of terracotta-coloured soil brought in from the west by huge dust storms. In New South Wales, firefighters were tackling 95 blazes, but they were all at the lowest warning levels. In Victoria state, one out of 60 fires was rated at the warning level of watch and act"
column33: meaning there was no immediate danger."

column1: Australia to probe crash that killed three US firefighters=24 Jan 2020 08:29AM (Updated: 24 Jan 2020 09:16AM)=AFP/rw=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australia-bushfires-probe-crash-killed-three-us-firefighters-12319334=" SYDNEY: Police investigators will join a probe into the crash of a firefighting plane that killed three American crew helping to battle Australia's devastating bushfires
column2: officials said Friday. The Hercules C-130 water-bombing aircraft erupted in a fireball on impact in the Snowy Mountains on Thursday as firefighters raced to tackle another outbreak of the deadly blazes. Hazardous materials specialists were working to secure the crash site before air transport safety investigators can begin sifting through the evidence with police support. Authorities said three men aged 42
column3: 43 and 45 were believed to be on board at the time of the crash
column4: which left no survivors. Their deaths brought the toll in the bushfires to 32 since September
column5: with New South Wales hardest hit in what the state's Emergency Services Minister
column6: David Elliott
column7: called "the darkest summer of the state's history". Flags were being flown at half mast across the state on Friday in their honour. At a farewell for 32 US and Canadian firefighters who arrived in Australia before Christmas to help fight the blazes
column8: New South Wales Rural Fire Service commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons paid tribute to the three dead. "We will be forever indebted to the enormous contribution -- indeed the ultimate sacrifice -- that's been paid as a result of these extraordinary individuals doing a remarkable job
column9: as they have done for years now in New South Wales
column10: he said. Canadian firm Coulson Aviation owned the plane and had been contracted to help fight fires in Australia. Representatives from the company were due to arrive in Australia on Saturday, while the families of the victims were also expected to travel to Australia in the coming days. Fitzsimmons said this fire season was proving to be truly tragic
column11: extended
column12: damaging (and) destructive". Six volunteer firefighters were also seriously injured when a water truck rolled near the fire-threatened town of Batemans Bay
column13: on the state's south coast
column14: on Thursday night. New South Wales Deputy Premier John Barilaro told public broadcaster ABC it was suspected some could be suffering spinal injuries. "You can see clearly it's tough conditions and our volunteers are going beyond the norm to try to protect community and lives
column15: he said. Firefighters had been battling dangerous blazes Thursday, as strong winds and temperatures reaching above 40 degrees Celsius sparked new fires across Australia's southeast before conditions eased Friday. A new heatwave is forecast for next week and could fuel a new flare-up of wildfires. A state memorial service will be held for all fallen firefighters and others killed in the fires at a later date.

column1: Koala bushfire victims start to return home amid wider fears for Australia’s wildlife==CNA/jb=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australia-bushfires-koalas-wombats-injuries-burns-12302962=" ADELAIDE
column2: Australia: At Paradise Primary School
column3: boxes and boxes of koalas are lined up on the floor of a gymnasium. Volunteers and veterinarians tend to the animals
column4: all victims of damaging bushfires that swept through South Australia in late December. This makeshift emergency triage centre for wounded koalas has been a site of both tears and triumph over the past few weeks. Death has never been far away as the team at Adelaide Koala Rescue (AKR) has responded to hundreds of calls to help animals burnt
column5: displaced and starving as a result of the fires. But for dozens of the koalas left here now
column6: home is calling.  There have been staggering losses to Australia’s wildlife this summer
column7: as bushfires ripped through more than 10 million hectares of land. Experts predict that some 1.25 billion animals
column8: including mammals
column9: birds and reptiles
column10: have been killed nationwide. The number reaches into the trillions when insects and other invertebrates
column11: all essential to delicate ecosystems
column12: are counted. And still
column13: the blazes rage. While the casualty rates and long term impact on the environment are hard to fathom
column14: those working tirelessly to save and recuperate the survivors have been left holding onto small positives. For AKR
column15: it comes in the form of paper signs at the entrance to their triage centre. On it is listed the names of all of the koalas who have successfully “graduated” back to the wild. Each of them - like Spud and Janet and Alice Cooper - is a “cause for celebration”
column16: according to director Jane Brister.   “I think more than anything
column17: it’s important for the morale for our volunteers
column18: ” she said. “It’s been a really traumatic time for a lot of the team members
column19: especially the ones that go out in the field. I’ve certainly seen things that I can’t unsee.” Brister estimates that AKR has retrieved more than 300 koalas from scorched areas within the past three weeks
column20: and cared for up to 120 wild animals at any one time. Each animal has different medical treatment needs - from burnt paws to singed ears and dehydration - but all of them require housing
column21: food and a bit of love
column22: during what is a traumatic and confusing period. “What people love about them the most and what upsets people the most when it comes to bushfires is their innocence and their vulnerability. They can’t fly away
column23: they can’t run away
column24: ” she said.   “They’re stuck there up a tree and they’re really defenceless. They have to rely on us to fight for them
column25: to fight for their habitat and I think that’s in part what makes them so endearing.” Despite the easing of the worst fire conditions in South Australia
column26: here and right across bushfire affected areas
column27: finding relocation refuges for rehabilitated or dislocated wildlife is proving to be a difficult challenge. For those survivors hanging on in burnt out areas
column28: the situation is desperate too.   ‘THEY’RE ALL BASICALLY GONE’ In Majors Creek
column29: a small rural community close to Canberra
column30: Bill Waterhouse and his wife Lesley run a wombat refuge
column31: which has quickly transformed into a rescue operation for a menagerie of wildlife. “This morning a little baby wombat was brought to us
column32: I was called out for a kangaroo hanging in a fence and on the way home I brought home a magpie
column33: ” Waterhouse said.  The couple have been responding to rescue requests since bushfires reared up in their area in early December. The danger has not passed and they constantly live in fear of another evacuation from their property
column34: which is home to several injured animals.   “We feel like we’re under siege
column35: personally here
column36: but we also feel like all the animals we’ve cared about for so many years are now being burnt to death and now our release sites and their carers are under attack
column37: ” he said. “I’d be lying if I said I wasn’t feeling a sense of anguish about it.” Local areas that used to be safe havens for the animals they released back into the wild are now affected by fire. There are few safe places left. On the back of donations
column38: Waterhouse is attempting to mobilise local landowners to try and provide much needed food on the edges of the fireground where wild animals are coming to scavenge. But he has been left saddened by the lack of animals that appear to be in need of help. “There have been very few animals brought to us
column39: burnt or not. In general
column40: with the amount of damage that’s taken place
column41: we were expecting many more but it’s been so hot and so devastating that they’re all basically gone
column42: ” he said.   “We think the animals are increasingly going to be hungry
column43: they’ll be desperate. There’s no flowers out there
column44: there are no leaves
column45: there are no nests. “The canopy
column46: if it wasn’t burnt
column47: it was scorched. You really notice the silence. The habitat’s had it. There’s pockets left but the fire is indiscriminate. I think it’s just too late for the vast majority. Lesley paces through the couple’s home with a tiny baby wombat tucked into her chest. With electricity still out in the area
column48: the heat pads used to keep the small creatures warm are not working. Little Jack
column49: as he has been dubbed
column50: was found in the pouch of his dead mother
column51: who had been struck by a car
column52: a common accident during this period of prolonged drought and fire.   “The nature of the road is it's warm and water runs off it. So there’s almost always a little bit of greenery on the roadside and animals are drawn to it
column53: ” Waterhouse said. “He’s a little pinkie and has no fur yet. He’s the size of a sweet potato with little legs and wriggly bits. It has a very good chance of surviving all the way through. It’s a two year program for him.” Waterhouse and other rescuers are bracing for the long haul care of wildlife amid the widespread habitat destruction. But while koalas
column54: wombats and other generalist Australian species will inevitably bounce back
column55: there are greater fears that lesser known
column56: critically threatened species may have already been lost.   FACING EXTINCTION Analysis by the Australian Department of Environment and Energy shows that 49 threatened species have had more than 80 per cent of their likely or known distribution area affected by fire. A further 65 species have had at least half of their habitats burnt. “If the habitat of those species is removed
column57: then there are real fears for whether they can persist. These would be species extinctions
column58: things that occur here uniquely that won’t occur anymore
column59: ” said Chris Dickman
column60: a professor of ecology at the University of Sydney. “It’s clearly a really emotional time for anyone associated with the native fauna. It’s awful to see the pictures and it’s awful to know there’s a whole lot more behind them
column61: ” he added. Prof Dickman says while iconic
column62: charismatic animals are important for raising awareness about the damage to natural environments
column63: there are many
column64: many others that are essential to ecosystem balance that have suffered major losses.   “It may be ecologically important species that carry out functions like pollination or moving seeds around in the forest environment
column65: or are important because they move fungal spores
column66: or digging the topsoil. If these are lost
column67: then it means the ability of the forest ecosystem to regenerate in the future will be slowed down or compromised
column68: ” he said. But the Australian bush is known to be resilient and he says in some areas
column70: the recovery of habitats could be “rapid”. The federal government has pledged A$50 million (US$34m) for a Wildlife and Habitat Recovery Package that will be used to try to prevent species extinction and enable the work of local wildlife rescuers. But opposition figures
column71: like Senator Mehreen Faruqi from the Australian Greens
column72: says that money “is just a drop in the ocean”. “Really what we need at this time is an open chequebook from the government because that is the only thing that will ensure the survival of our species and our native species into the future
column73: ” she said. “Wildlife carers have been working around the clock to save the animals
column74: to protect the animals and to rehabilitate animals but you know this is really expensive work
column75: it is time consuming work and it is absolutely emotionally draining work.”   The tired eyes of the volunteers at the koala triage centre are testament to the fatigue and stress inflicted upon them these past weeks. But for each koala carried out in their hamper - their name added to the list on the door - destined for a return to a eucalyptus tree somewhere in the Adelaide Hills
column76: a feeling of optimism infectiously hovers over the gym. It comes even though there is a deep understanding that thousands of others have died. It is the small positives that matter right now."

column18: with air quality rated as good. Last week
column19: a player collapsed in a coughing fit from bushfire smoke during qualifying rounds at the tournament. Since September
column20: hundreds of wildfires in Australia have killed 29 people as well as an estimated 1 billion native animals
column21: while incinerating 2
column22: 500 homes and a total area of bushland one-third the size of Germany. A Reuters analysis shows that Australian animals living in specific habitats
column23: such as mountain lizards
column24: leaf-tailed geckos and pear-shaped frogs
column25: are battling the threat of extinction after fierce bushfires razed large areas of their homes. The disaster hit the Christmas and summer holiday season
column26: emptying out caravan parks and hotels
column27: devastating peak earnings for businesses dependent on domestic and foreign tourists. The Australian Tourism Industry Council estimated the revenue loss industry-wide at A$2 billion (US$1.4 billion)
column28: including forward sales and the physical damage to tourism facilities across regions ravaged by bushfires. "Whatever the numbers ultimately land at
column29: it's had a significant impact
column30: said Simon Westaway, executive director of the council, which represents small and medium-sized tourism businesses. Cancellation rates hit 100% in fire-affected areas while tourist facilities even in areas not affected by fires were hit with cancellation rates of around 60%, and there is evidence of international booking cancellations too, he said. People see a state of emergency and don't know if they'll be able to get in or out
column31: Westaway told Reuters. This contagion has really swept across the industry.""

column1: Removing hazards as important as reducing emissions: Australian PM Morrison==Reuters/de=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/removing-hazards-as-important-as-reducing-emissions-australian-12299086=" SYDNEY: Prime Minister Scott Morrison said removing flammable vegetation is as important as reducing emissions if Australia is to prevent future bushfires
column2: comments that are likely to stoke public anger. Morrison is under intense pressure for his government's handing of a bushfire crisis that has killed 29 people and millions of animals
column3: destroyed more than 2
column4: 500 homes and razed 11 million hectares of wilderness - an area one-third the size of Germany. The scores of fires follow three years of drought that experts have linked to climate change
column5: but Morrison said late on Tuesday (Jan 21) that his critics are too focussed on carbon emissions. "Hazard reduction is as important as emissions reduction and many would argue
column6: I think
column7: even more so because it has even more direct practical impact on the safety of a person going into a bushfire season
column8: Morrison told Sky News Australia. Australia is one of the largest carbon emitters per capita due to its reliance on coal-fired power plants, and Morrison is a firm supporter of the industry. Morrison's comments came as Australian authorities braced for a return of soaring temperatures and strong winds - conditions that firefighters fear will fan dozens of blazes still burning. Temperatures in Victoria state are expected to top more than 32 degrees Celsius, leading officials to declare extreme fire danger" in some areas. Australia's most populous state
column9: New South Wales has enjoyed several days of cooler weather in recent days
column10: but temperatures on Thursday will hit 40 degrees C
column11: the country's weather bureau said. Sydney and Melbourne have been repeatedly blanketed in thick smoke that has resulted in air quality ratings among the worst in the world. Here are today's key events in the bushfire crisis: - As of Wednesday
column12: 79 fires were burning across New South Wales
column13: none above the lowest warning level. There were 25 emergency warnings in Victoria. - Australian animals living in specific habitats
column14: such as mountain lizards
column15: leaf-tailed geckos and pear-shaped frogs
column16: are battling the threat of extinction after fierce bushfires razed large areas of their homes
column17: a new Reuters analysis shows. - Former Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott downplayed the link between the bushfires and climate change in a speech in Washington. - The Australian Open tennis tournament continues in Melbourne. The city's air quality was rated as "good"
column18: according to the Air Quality Index
column19: having been "hazardous" less than a week earlier."

column1: Tennis: Bushfire crisis cools notorious Kyrgios temper===https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/sport/tennis-bushfire-crisis-cools-notorious-kyrgios-temper-12296888=""
In forest monastery
column2: Buddhist abbot faces Australia bushfire with a smile=21 Jan 2020 06:57PM (Updated: 21 Jan 2020 06:59PM)=Reuters/zl=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australia-fires-new-south-wales-buddhist-monastery-sunnataram-12296428=" BUNDANOON
column3: Australia: Buddhist monk Phra Mana helped build his bush monastery with his bare hands three decades ago
column4: but when Australia's worst wildfires in generations threatened to destroy it he stood up to fate with a smile. An inferno ripped through the forest surrounding the Sunnataram Monastery in New South Wales two weeks ago and
column5: after being evacuated
column6: he and his fellow monks could do nothing but pray. "I have never seen branches behave like this in the past 30 years
column7: the Bangkok-born abbot said, describing how dry the land was. So when the heat came
column8: it just burnt so quick." This season's bushfires have razed an area equivalent to half of the UK
column9: killed millions of animals
column10: devastated rural communities and cost farmers and vintners their livelihoods.   At the monastery
column11: which around 50 to 60 volunteer firefighters were dispatched to defend
column12: only a few buildings and water tanks were lost. True to his religion
column13: Phra Mana has been able to accept the damage with equanimity. "Wildfires are normal in Australia's bushland
column14: the 56-year-old said as he strolled around the scorched compound in orange robes. As long as our faith and morale remain strong
column15: we are prepared to face it." The Buddha statues gracing the compound still stand
column16: and now the monks have added a message spelling out "Thank you Firey"
column17: addressed to the firefighters. But the monastery remains under threat as a nearby forest continues to smoulder. "We are prepared. At the same time
column18: we accept
column19: Phra Mana said.

column1: Australian bushfires scathe sanctuary for rare bee species===https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australian-bushfires-scathe-sanctuary-for-rare-bee-species-12295766=" KANGAROO ISLAND
column2: Australia: Bees swarm around Peter Davis as he unloads his precious
column3: buzzing cargo into their new home in a part of South Australia's Kangaroo Island that was not devastated by recent bushfires. After losing almost half of his 1
column4: 200 hives of Ligurian bees to the blazes on the island
column5: Davis hopes relocating the remainder to unburnt forest and a food supply of eucalypt sugar gums will save them.   Kangaroo Island
column6: about 15
column7: 000km away from the Ligurian bees' ancestral home of Italy
column8: is believed to host the world's last genetically pure population of the species. The bees were imported to South Australia in 1885 and officials banned the introduction of any other bee species or honey since
column9: making it a sanctuary for Ligurian bees. Italy's pure stock of the bees was wiped out due to interbreeding and disease. Bushfires burnt a third of Kangaroo Island over New Year
column10: killing two people and destroying an estimated quarter of the island's 4
column11: 000 Ligurian hives as well as the eucalypts that feed that the bees. "The main tree for food at this time of the year is the Sugar Gum
column12: Eucalyptus cladocalyx
column13: that grows all along the North Coast which has been devastated by fire
column14: another Kangaroo Island Ligurian honey producer, David Clifford, told Reuters. So we are not going to get a honey supply from that this year and it will take 15 years for it to recover."     While Clifford's bees escaped the flames
column15: he said the insects appeared "very disorientated" and "more aggressive" than usual after they were relocated. Davis said the destruction has lost him about 20 tonnes of honey for this season alone and cost him an estimated A$500
column17: 000) including lost production from the surviving hives. Ligurian honey is used to make a range of high-end products including hand creams and candles.   Davis was only able to start moving his hives to a safer home this week
column18: having spent the last few weeks fighting fires. "We have been trying to protect neighbours
column19: trying to protect houses
column20: livestock
column21: he said. Davis urged the government to lift restrictions on the island that ban farmers from reducing fuel loads in bushland areas through preemptive burning. We wouldn't have lost farms and houses like we have if we had been allowed to burn and use fire as a management tool
column22: he said.
