column1: Weather 'merry-go-round' poses new risks for fire-ravaged Australia==AFP/aa=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/australia-fires-weather-poses-new-risks-for-firefighters-12295478=" SYDNEY: A "merry-go-round" of extreme weather has been hampering efforts by firefighters in Australia to tackle unprecedented bushfires that have killed at least 29 people and devastated vast swathes of the country. Parts of the country welcomed heavy rainfall overnight
column2: but authorities warned Tuesday (Jan 21) that storms were bringing added complications
column3: and the fire-danger risk could be elevated in the coming days. "It has been a merry-go-round of weather over the last few days
column4: the Bureau of Meteorology's Kevin Parkin said. We have gone from fires and storms and floods
column5: and giant hail - the size of limes ... producing widespread damage - to fire danger escalating on our doorstep
column6: the senior meteorologist added. The country has suffered a collision of extreme climate events in the past week, with storms, lightning, thunder and hail battering areas in the fire-hit east. The bushfire season has been made worse by climate change, experts say. Victoria state experienced bursts of intense rain over the past 48 hours that helped to contain long-running blazes in some areas, but landslides, fallen trees and lightning strikes have hampered recovery efforts. The temperature in Victoria is set to climb into the mid-30 degrees Celsius range on Wednesday amid fierce winds, prompting extreme weather warnings in the western parts of the state, where authorities say new start" fires will be difficult to contain. "New starts in unprepared communities are the biggest risk
column7: Victoria Country Fire Authority chief officer Steve Warrington told media. If communities are not prepared for fire - whether they live or die
column8: whether their property is saved or not saved - is very much dependent on decisions people make right now." A change is expected to bring more rain to the state late Wednesday. Further north in New South Wales state
column9: heavy rains have also been welcomed in some areas but in others it has left fire-ravaged areas too damp to undertake preventative controlled burns. Authorities there are bracing for elevated fire danger on Thursday
column10: when temperatures in parts of the state will tip above 40 degrees Celsius."

column1: 5 COVID-19 patients in Singapore discharged from hospital
column2: 2 new cases reported=17 Feb 2020 08:04PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 08:25PM)=CNA/hs=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid19-coronavirus-singapore-update-feb-17-12441176=" SINGAPORE: Five more COVID-19 patients in Singapore have been discharged from hospital
column3: said the Ministry of Health (MOH) in a daily update on Monday (Feb 17). In all
column4: 24 cases have fully recovered from the infection and have been discharged from hospital. Two new COVID-19 cases were also reported on Monday
column5: bringing the total number of confirmed cases in Singapore to 77. Case 76 is a one-year-old Singaporean who was among the group evacuated from Wuhan on Feb 9. The toddler was without symptoms when he boarded the flight back to Singapore. He was put under quarantine upon landing in Singapore
column6: and was confirmed to be infected with COVID-19 on Sunday afternoon. He is currently warded in an isolation room at KK Women's and Children's Hospital
column7: said MOH. "All Singaporeans evacuated from Wuhan were tested for COVID-19 as an added precaution
column8: MOH said. Case 77 is a 35-year-old Singaporean man who has no recent travel history to China. He is a close contact of Case 50, a 62-year-old Singaporean who works at DBS. The 35-year-old was tested positive for the infection on Monday morning and is currently warded at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID).    Singapore raised its Disease Outbreak Response System Condition (DORSCON) level to Orange on Feb 7, prompting additional precautionary measures. Earlier on Monday, MOH announced a new Stay-Home Notice for Singapore residents and long-term pass holders with recent travel history to mainland China outside the Hubei province. From Tuesday, such travellers will be required to stay home at all times during their 14-day leave period. This is stricter than the Leave of Absence measure currently in place, which allows them to leave their homes briefly, for example for meals or to buy household supplies. COVID-19 has killed more than 1,700 and infected more than 70,500 in mainland China. It has spread to more than 25 countries, including Singapore, Japan and Thailand. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the novel coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram

column1: COVID-19: New Stay-Home Notice with stricter measures for Singapore residents
column2: long-term pass holders returning from mainland China=17 Feb 2020 05:34PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 06:30PM)=CNA/hs(mi)=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid19-coronavirus-stay-at-home-leave-china-singapore-12442116=" SINGAPORE: The Ministry of Health (MOH) on Monday (Feb 17) announced a new Stay-Home Notice (SHN) for Singapore residents and long-term pass holders returning to Singapore from mainland China. As part of the notice requirements
column3: such travellers will have to remain in their homes at all times during the 14-day leave period. This is stricter than the Leave of Absence (LOA) currently in place
column4: which allows them to leave their homes briefly
column5: for example to have their meals or buy household supplies. The SHN will take effect from 11.59pm on Tuesday and will apply to all returnees with recent travel history to China (outside Hubei) within the last 14 days.  With the implementation of the SHN
column6: the Government will no longer be issuing LOAs to such returnees
column7: the health ministry said. "The vast majority on the present regime would have served out their LOAs in the coming days and we will continue to ensure their compliance in the meantime
column8: said MOH. The SHN will also cover returning workers from mainland China on work passes. For such workers
column9: we already require employers to seek prior approval from the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) before they travel to Singapore. If employers need help
column10: MOM will link them up with hotels or dormitory operators for their workers to serve out the SHN
column11: said the health ministry. MOH said the implementation of the SHN is another precautionary measure we are taking to minimise the risk of additional imported cases of COVID-19". Similar to those placed on LOA
column12: these travellers are not suspected to have been in close contact with confirmed cases of COVID-19 infection
column13: nor are they unwell or display symptoms of the virus. "These individuals are bearing inconvenience for the benefit of the wider community
column14: said MOH. We therefore urge all landlords to cooperate and to allow their tenants who are placed on SHN to serve out their full-14 day requirements
column15: it added. The Government said it would continue to implement surveillance and enforcement measures to ensure compliance to the SHN requirements. There will also be support for those who need help during their SHN period, for example access to food and other daily necessities. Singapore citizens, permanent residents and long-term visit pass holders can seek help from the People's Association. Students can get help from their schools or institutions, or the Ministry of Education. Those on work passes can look for their employers or MOM. 1,200 PEOPLE ON QUARANTINE: LAWRENCE WONG Speaking to reporters on Monday, Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong said that there are 1,200 people on quarantine to date. About half of them are in Government quarantine facilities, while the rest are quarantined at home.  The SHN is similar to the Home Quarantine Order, with differences in the requirements for physical isolation. The quarantine order is served to people who have come into close contact with individuals who have been infected, while those serving the SHN are not suspected to have had such exposure. Those under the Home Quarantine Order need to be separated from other people within the home"
column16: said Mr Wong. In comparison
column17: the SHN allows people to share a room with their family members
column18: he added. However
column19: Mr Wong said those who live under one roof with family members under the SHN could practice "common sense" and good hygiene when it comes to preparing food and the use of common utensils. Responding to a question
column20: Mr Wong also said that visits from outsiders were discouraged
column21: but if close family members wanted to visit individuals placed under the SHN
column22: they should take "some precautions". The main requirement is that those served with the SHN do not leave their homes
column23: he added. Long-term pass holders will have their passes revoked if they flout the rules of the SNH
column24: while Singaporeans and permanent residents may face prosecution under the Infectious Diseases Act
column25: said Mr Wong. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the novel coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: COVID-19 threat could erode with time just as with H1N1
column2: say experts=17 Feb 2020 06:14AM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 08:05AM)=CNA/hw=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid-19-threat-could-erode-with-time-just-as-with-h1n1-say-12438600=" SINGAPORE: The outbreak of COVID-19 infections that started in Wuhan
column3: China and has now spread to almost 30 other countries including Singapore could follow the same trajectory seen in the H1N1 influenza outbreak in Mexico just over a decade ago. It could fade into something less sinister later on
column4: said infectious disease experts. In early March 2009
column5: Mexico experienced outbreaks of respiratory illness and increased reports of patients with flu-like symptoms in several areas of the country. This new human H1N1 strain
column6: which originated from swine flu in pigs
column7: swept across the world and by the World Health Organization's (WHO) estimate
column8: was responsible for more than 18
column9: 000 deaths globally in the 2009 pandemic. JUST ANOTHER FLU BUG WHO declared the virus a public health emergency on Apr 24
column10: 2009. Four days later
column11: Singapore raised its Disease Outbreak Response (DORSCON) from Green to Yellow. This was raised to Orange on Apr 30
column12: when the WHO raised its pandemic alert level from phase 4 to phase 5. But it was not until May 26
column13: 2009 that Singapore saw its first case of H1N1
column14: 15 days after the Ministry of Health (MOH) revised the DORSCON alert back down to Yellow. A 22-year-old undergraduate returning from New York had developed symptoms on the flight and later tested positive for the virus. The outbreak in Singapore peaked in Aug 2009
column15: and the country saw 18 H1N1 fatalities in that year. By the time the DORSCON alert was lowered from yellow to green on Feb 21
column17: about 415
column18: 000 people islandwide had been infected with the virus
column19: with most experiencing mild illness. “Everyone then realised that it was just another flu bug. The initial deaths in Mexico were not seen in Singapore. Very surprising
column20: ” said Dr Leong Hoe Nam
column21: an infectious disease specialist at Mount Elizabeth Novena Hospital. “Now when you revisit Mexico
column22: the same virus circulates there
column23: but it doesn’t kill that much.” This is because the threat of H1N1 eroded over the years
column24: he added. And the same is likely to happen for COVID-19
column25: said experts CNA spoke to. VIRUSES BECOME MILDER OVER TIME: EXPERTS Professor Tikki Pang
column26: visiting professor at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy under the National University of Singapore (NUS) said the coronavirus causing the COVID-19 outbreak is likely to stabilise and eventually disappear from public consciousness. “This is the historical pattern of past pandemics
column27: and happens because the virus ‘burns out’ and runs out of people to infect as a result of many factors
column28: ” said Prof Pang
column29: citing warmer temperatures
column30: better public awareness and public health measures. “There is a possibility that the virus could mutate into something more ‘sinister’
column31: (that) spreads faster (or causes) more severe disease
column34: we have not seen any evidence of this happening.” According to Dr Leong
column35: there are four circulating coronaviruses that cause the common cold
column36: and one of them periodically causes severe pneumonia. “I believe they came into existence much like the current COVID-19. It killed many people and virology or technology was not sufficiently established then to identify the cause of the illness. But it became attenuated with time
column37: ” said Dr Leong. “COVID-19 will go the same way. What we need is time for it to accumulate mutations
column38: and it will become milder.” According to Dr Leong
column39: there is a “natural tendency” for viruses to mutate to something milder. If the virus is too pathogenic and it kills its host
column40: it is unable to continue spreading. But if it is mild
column41: it can continue to propagate and pass on to other individuals
column42: eventually picking up mutations that reduce the virus' ability to cause disease
column43: said Dr Leong. He noted that increasing awareness of H1N1 treatment and availability of vaccines also contributed to the threat fading. According to experts
column44: H1N1 is currently a dominant flu strain in Singapore
column45: although this may vary between seasons
column46: and flu vaccines provide immunity against it. Countries in the region face a similar situation - Taiwan's Centre for Disease Control said earlier this month that 56 patients there had died of H1N1 flu virus-affected respiratory failure in the past three months. In the years following the 2009 pandemic
column48: but has been on the increase in recent years
column49: said Professor Clarence Tam from the Saw Swee Hock School of Public Health
column50: NUS. "This is likely because
column51: after the pandemic
column52: many people were infected with H1N1 and developed immunity against this influenza strain
column53: so the virus couldn't spread as easily
column54: said Prof Tam. But we know that immunity against influenza is short-lived
column55: and as the level of immunity drops in the population
column56: more people are now becoming infected with this strain again." Dr Leong said: “It becomes another flu bug. And it helps with the fact that Singaporeans cannot distinguish between flu and the common cold
column57: making the concept of flu in Singapore much milder. “People soon became complacent of H1N1. But
column58: some lethality maintained. If there is a bad case of influenza in the intensive care (unit)
column59: it would usually be a H1N1 (case). But overall
column60: we see less and less of a problem.” TRANSMISSION OF COVID-19
column61: H1N1 SIMILAR Speaking at a press conference on Friday (Feb 14)
column62: Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong had said that it is “clearly emerging” that COVID-19 is different from Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) and has more similarities with H1N1. “The transmission mechanism of COVID-19 is different from SARS. In fact
column63: the transmission mechanism is closer to H1N1 or influenza
column64: ” said Mr Wong. Researchers at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) have confirmed this
column67: COVID-19 is infectious when symptoms are mild. Because of this transmission mechanism
column70: can spread “quite quickly”
column71: said Mr Wong. “With our mild symptoms
column72: we sometimes let our guard down - we continue going out even though we don’t really feel well
column73: and that’s how the virus transmits
column74: ” he added. Mr Wong also said it was “a matter of time” before “a lot of people around the world” will be infected with COVID-19. Citing the widespread community transmission seen in the 2009 H1N1 pandemic
column75: Mr Wong said: “We’re not saying that this will happen for COVID-19. It’s a different disease than H1N1 so the patterns of transmission and the number of people contracting the disease will be different
column76: ” he said. "But because the transmission patterns are similar to H1N1
column77: we should be prepared for a scenario where you get wider transmission around the world.” Prof Tam stressed that even if the risk of mortality from a virus is low
column78: it can still cause a large number of deaths if it spreads easily
column79: citing the current COVID-19 outbreak as an example. “The available data indicate that this new virus is not as deadly as SARS
column80: but spreads much more readily from person to person. Consequently
column81: the number of reported deaths has already surpassed deaths from SARS in less than two months
column82: ” he said. “The same applies for influenza viruses. Even though the proportion of all influenza cases that succumb to the disease is low
column85: 000 people worldwide die each year from influenza.” Adding that it is “difficult to predict” whether the COVID-19 will take the same route as the H1N1 pandemic
column86: Prof Tam said: “The concern is that if current efforts to contain the virus aren’t ultimately enough to stamp out human transmission
column87: it could spread rapidly across the globe causing many more hospitalisations and deaths before a vaccine can be developed or enough immunity builds up in the population to bring the epidemic under control.” Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: Singapore cuts 2020 GDP forecast range to -0.5% to 1.5% due to COVID-19 outbreak=17 Feb 2020 08:11AM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 02:25PM)=CNA/mn=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/singapore-cuts-2020-gdp-forecast-covid-19-economy-12440764=" SINGAPORE: After seeing its economy grow at a decade-low of 0.7 per cent last year
column2: Singapore is expecting possibly even slower growth in 2020 and has downgraded its gross domestic product (GDP) forecast amid concerns about the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak. Economic growth for this year is expected to come in at around 0.5 per cent
column3: the mid-point of a new estimated range of between -0.5 per cent and 1.5 per cent
column4: said the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) on Monday (Feb 17). The previous forecast range announced last November was 0.5 per cent to 2.5 per cent. Singapore has so far confirmed 75 cases of the novel coronavirus
column5: with authorities earlier this month raising the Disease Outbreak Response System Condition (DORSCON) to Orange. Last week
column6: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak will have a significant impact on the local economy for the next couple of quarters. MTI said its earlier forecast was premised on a modest pick-up in global growth and a recovery in the global electronics cycle this year. However
column7: the outbreak of COVID-19 has affected many countries around the world
column8: including Singapore
column9: and is likely to dampen the growth prospects of China and those impacted. In China
column10: GDP growth in 2020 will likely come in lower than earlier projected due to a pullback in household consumption as a result of the lockdowns and travel restrictions implemented in several major Chinese cities to contain the spread of the novel coronavirus
column11: it said. Industrial production has also been disrupted due to work stoppages and delays arising from these containment measures
column12: MTI noted in its report. These will
column13: in turn
column14: have a knock-on impact on regional economies through lower outbound tourism and other import demand from China
column15: as well as disruptions to supply chains
column16: it added. “Should the COVID-19 outbreak be more widespread
column17: severe and protracted than anticipated
column18: there could be a sharper pullback in global consumption
column19: as well as more prolonged disruptions to global supply chains and production
column20: ” the report said. MTI also cautioned that a sharper-than-expected economic slowdown in China due to the virus outbreak will negatively affect global trade and economic growth. At the same time
column21: other uncertainties in the global economy remain
column22: such as the US-China trade war and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East
column23: it added. As a result
column24: the outlook for the Singapore economy has weakened since its last review in November
column25: the ministry said
column26: adding that the ongoing COVID-19 situation could impact the local economy through several channels. First
column27: the outward-oriented sectors
column28: such as manufacturing and wholesale trade
column29: will be affected by the weaker growth outlook in several of Singapore’s key final demand markets
column30: including China. Firms in these sectors could also be affected by supply chain disruptions arising from prolonged factory closures and labour shortages in China. Second
column31: there has been a sharp fall in tourist arrivals
column33: and this has badly affected the local tourism and transport sectors. Third
column34: domestic consumption is likely to decline as locals cut back on shopping and dining-out activities. This will adversely affect firms in segments such as retail and food services
column35: the ministry noted. MTI permanent secretary Gabriel Lim said at a press conference that the hit on GDP growth is likely to be felt during the first two quarters of the year
column36: although the impact through these three channels could play out further down the road and will need to be closely watched. The ministry emphasised that while its latest GDP forecast range includes the possibility of a recession
column37: that is not its central scenario and its baseline view is for the economy to see positive growth at around 0.5 per cent for 2020. “As the COVID-19 situation is still evolving
column38: there is a significant degree of uncertainty over the length and severity of the outbreak
column39: and hence its overall impact on the Singapore economy
column40: ” Mr Lim said. “MTI will continue to monitor developments and their impact on the Singapore economy closely.” The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said its monetary policy remains unchanged
column41: as it had highlighted in a statement earlier this month. The central bank is monitoring developments very closely and its next policy review remains as scheduled in April
column42: its deputy managing director Edward Robinson told reporters. 2019 GROWTH SLOWEST IN A DECADE MTI’s report on Monday also showed the Singapore economy expanded by 1 per cent year-on-year in the last quarter of 2019
column43: slightly above the Government’s initial estimate of 0.8 per cent and the 0.7 per cent growth in the earlier quarter. On a quarter-on-quarter seasonally adjusted annualised basis
column44: growth came in at 0.6 per cent. This is way below the 2.2 per cent expansion in the third quarter
column45: but above the 0.1 per cent flash estimate. This brings the full-year growth in 2019 to 0.7 per cent
column46: a sharp slowdown from 2018’s 3.4 per cent and hitting the country’s lowest growth since the global financial crisis in 2009. The manufacturing sector was the biggest laggard last year. It contracted by 1.4 per cent
column48: due to output declines in the electronics
column49: chemicals
column50: precision engineering and transport engineering clusters. Construction expanded by 2.8 per cent
column51: turning around from the 3.5 per cent contraction in 2018
column52: supported by both public sector and private sector construction works. The services producing industries also grew by 1.1 per cent
column53: albeit moderating from the 3.4 per cent growth in 2018. Growth largely came from the finance and insurance
column54: other services and business services sectors. For this year
column55: there are still expectations for a “modest growth” in the manufacturing sector
column56: although authorities are closely watching for the impact of COVID-19 on clusters
column58: which have been showing some signs of a tentative rebound
column59: said Economic Development Board’s assistant managing director Kelvin Wong. There are also pockets of relative strength in the Singapore economy
column60: such as the construction sector which is projected to post steady growth given the rebound in construction demand since 2018. The information and communications sector is also expected to be resilient on account of sustained enterprise demand for IT solutions
column61: MTI said. ALL EYES ON “STRONG” BUDGET 2020 Given how the economy is likely to feel the strain from the flu-like virus
column62: economists say a “strong” relief package will likely be announced on Tuesday as part of the Budget
column63: as the Government had promised. Maybank Kim Eng economists
column64: for instance
column65: are pencilling help of at least S$700 million – way higher than the S$230 million relief package released during 2003’s severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreak. Measures to support the hardest-hit sectors may range from tax rebates for commercial
column67: lower foreign worker levies for tourism-related sectors to bridging loans for smaller firms. The two integrated resorts
column70: the economists said. DBS senior economist Irvin Seah is expecting the Government to put forth an overall deficit of about S$7.9 billion in Budget 2020
column71: the biggest in a decade. “A strong fiscal response is expected to mitigate the impact of the virus outbreak
column72: ” he wrote in a note. OCBC Bank head of treasury research and strategy Selena Ling also expects an overall budget deficit of about S$8 billion
column73: which will include a “sizeable COVID-19 relief package and a GST offset package”. And if the deadly virus chills growth further
column74: monetary policy easing will likely be on the cards. Ms Ling said: “Policymakers are also cognizant of the downside growth risks so a strong Budget response and/or monetary policy response in April may help to mitigate and cushion some of the downside risks. “At this juncture
column75: we do not rule out the possibility of the MAS reverting to a zero appreciation path for the S$NEER (Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate) and regard a re-centering lower as the lower-probability event
column76: ” she added. Separately on Monday
column77: Enterprise Singapore cut its 2020 forecasts for non-oil domestic exports (NODX) and total merchandise trade
column78: citing likely impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak on its trading partners and lower oil prices. Both NODX and total merchandise are now expected to come in between -0.5 per cent to 1.5 per cent this year
column79: down from an earlier projection of zero to 2 per cent growth. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the Wuhan virus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: China coronavirus death toll surpasses 1
column2: 700; decline in new cases outside Hubei=17 Feb 2020 07:29AM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 09:46AM)=Agencies/mn=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/china-covid-19-coronavirus-wuhan-virus-hubei-new-cases-12440692=" BEIJING: The death toll from China's new coronavirus epidemic jumped to 1
column3: 770 after 105 more people died
column4: the National Health Commission said on Monday (Feb 17). More than 70
column5: 500 have now been infected nationwide by the virus
column6: which first emerged in December in central Hubei province before spreading across the country. Chinese authorities have placed about 56 million people in Hubei and its capital Wuhan under quarantine
column7: virtually sealing off the province from the rest of the country in an unprecedented effort to contain the virus. New cases outside of the epicentre have been declining for the last 13 days. There were 115 fresh cases outside the central province
column8: according to the commission on Monday - sharply down from nearly 450 a week ago. Local authorities elsewhere in China have introduced measures to try and stop the virus spreading
column9: including a rule in Beijing requiring people coming to the capital to self-quarantine for 14 days
column10: according to official media. Most cases are still in Hubei
column11: where nearly 2
column12: 000 were reported on Monday.   The number of reported infections ballooned on Thursday last week after Hubei authorities changed their criteria for counting cases
column13: retroactively adding 14
column14: 000 cases in a single day. Monday's figures for new cases were around 100 higher than those on Sunday but still sharply down on those from Friday and Saturday. A spokesman for China's national health authority said that the slowdown was a sign the outbreak was being controlled. However
column15: World Health Organization chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has warned it is "impossible to predict which direction this epidemic will take". International experts have arrived in Beijing and begun meeting with their Chinese counterparts over the epidemic
column16: Tedros said on Twitter. Outside mainland China
column17: Taipei officials reported the island's first death from the new coronavirus on Sunday
column18: as a 61-year-old man from central Taiwan with underlying health problems but no recent overseas travel history died in hospital. He is the fifth person outside of the mainland to die from the virus
column19: with the other deaths in the Philippines
column20: Hong Kong
column21: Japan and France. The biggest cluster outside China is on a quarantined cruise ship outside Japan with 356 infections confirmed
column22: including a quarantine officer. A top US health official on Sunday said 40 Americans from the ship have become infected and would be treated in Japan. Other Americans left the Diamond Princess into the early hours of Monday for chartered jets that would fly them home - and into further quarantine. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the COVID-19 outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: 14 test positive among US plane evacuees from Japan cruise ship=17 Feb 2020 03:28PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 06:12PM)=AFP/hs=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/covid-19-diamond-princess-14-evacuees-infected-united-states-12441826=" WASHINGTON: Fourteen people who had tested positive for the new coronavirus were among more than 300 US citizens and family members evacuated by plane from a quarantined ship in Japan
column2: the US State Department said Monday (Feb 17). The passengers had already disembarked from the Diamond Princess and were preparing to return to the United States on chartered aircraft when US officials were informed 14 of them who had been tested days earlier were positive for COVID-19
column3: it said in a joint statement with the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). After consultation with HHS
column4: the State Department decided to allow them on board
column5: but isolated them from the other passengers. "These individuals were moved in the most expeditious and safe manner to a specialised containment area on the evacuation aircraft to isolate them in accordance with standard protocols
column6: it said. During the flights
column7: these individuals will continue to be isolated from the other passengers." All passengers were being closely monitored throughout the flights. "Any who become symptomatic will be moved to the specialised containment area
column8: where they will be treated
column9: the statement said. The first flight is due to land shortly at a US Air Force base in California, where all passengers will undergo a 14-day quarantine, while a second plane is heading to another base in San Antonio, Texas. Another 99 people have tested positive for coronavirus on a cruise ship off the Japan coast, Japanese media said Monday, citing new figures from the health ministry. That would take the total number of positive cases on the Diamond Princess to 454. The health ministry declined to confirm the reports immediately. More than 600 people are already in quarantine in the United States, evacuated earlier from the virus epicentre in the Chinese city of Wuhan, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Friday. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram

column1: HipVan employee with COVID-19 had close contact with 3 colleagues
column2: stayed home after developing symptoms=17 Feb 2020 06:31PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 06:40PM)=CNA/hw(hm)=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/coronavirus-hipvan-employee-covid19-colleague-quarantine-case-70-12442098=" SINGAPORE: A 27-year-old Singaporean woman who was confirmed as Singapore’s 70th case of COVID-19 on Saturday (Feb 15) had close contact with three colleagues
column3: but did not go to work after developing symptoms
column4: said her employer HipVan. The patient is a full-time employee in HipVan’s merchandising department
column5: a HipVan spokesperson said. According to the Ministry of Health (MOH)
column6: she went to the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) on Feb 14
column7: after seeking treatment at a general practitioner clinic on Feb 3. She had flu-like symptoms from Feb 3 to Feb 7
column8: and was on medical leave that week
column9: said the HipVan spokesperson in response to CNA queries. The patient went back to work from Feb 10 to Feb 12 after recovering and did not exhibit any symptoms. But she felt unwell again on Feb 13 and was told to work from home. She did not come in to work after that
column10: said the spokesperson. The patient did not have any close contact with any clients or partners in the last two weeks
column11: but did have close contact with three colleagues who are now under home quarantine
column12: the spokesperson added. The three other employees have also been advised by MOH to take the necessary precautions to limit contact with their families
column13: she said. “Besides the three colleagues that have close contact with the patient
column14: our management team has also taken additional precautionary measures by getting all the staff that work from our Kallang office to work from home until further notice
column15: ” said the spokesperson. “We are also currently assisting MOH personnel with daily phone monitoring of all of our staff and so far
column16: no other staff has tested positive for the COVID-19 virus.” HipVan said it will also be working with the Health Ministry to disinfect its Kallang office and close its showroom to visitors until disinfection has been completed. “In addition
column17: we would also like the public to know that our warehouse and delivery teams
column18: managed by third-party service providers
column19: work out of a different location in Tuas
column20: and have had no close contact with the patient in the past weeks
column21: ” said the spokesperson.   The patient
column22: Case 70
column23: is a family member of Case 66
column24: linked to the Grace Assembly of God cluster. She stays at Mei Hwan Drive and had attended church services at God’s Kingdom Bread of Life Church prior to hospital admission
column25: said MOH on Sunday. On Sunday
column26: Singapore confirmed three new cases of COVID-19
column27: including a Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) regular serviceman
column28: bringing the total number of cases here to 75. There have been 18 confirmed cases linked to the Grace Assembly of God cluster so far. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the novel coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: Thailand reports new coronavirus case
column2: to increase entry screening=17 Feb 2020 02:10PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 02:30PM)=Reuters/hs=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/covid19-thailand-new-coronavirus-case-35-12441616=" BANGKOK: Thailand said on Monday (Feb 17) it had recorded one new case of the coronavirus and was increasing screening of visitors from Singapore and Japan entering the country in response to the widening outbreak. The new case
column3: a 60-year-old Chinese woman whose family members earlier contracted the virus
column4: takes the total number of cases in Thailand to 35 since January
column5: Sukhum Kanchanapimai
column6: the health ministry's permanent secretary told a news conference. "This is the from an old case of a Chinese family of nine
column7: all of them have now been infected
column8: he said. Fifteen of the infected people in Thailand have recovered and returned home, while 20 are still being treated in hospital. Some 1,770 people in China have died from the virus, along with a handful in other countries and territories but Thailand has not recorded any fatalities so far. Thai health authorities said they will expand virus screening to cover travellers from Japan and Singapore, in addition to those from mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan. Japan and Singapore have two of the highest numbers of reported cases outside China. Anyone from those places who displays coronavirus symptoms will be quarantined at a government hospital. Travellers from Japan and Singapore that developed a fever or respiratory symptoms within 14 days of entering the country will be treated like travellers from China
column9: Sukhum said. In addition, Thailand will not allow entry by any foreign nationals who were passengers of the Westerdam cruise ship, now docked in Cambodia, after an American woman tested positive for coronavirus in Malaysia over the weekend. There were 21 Thai nationals on board the ship and health authorities said all of them will be quarantined for 14 days when they enter Thailand. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram

column1: Did sneezing just give you back pain? It’s more common than you think=17 Feb 2020 06:30AM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 08:07AM)=CNA/bk=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/lifestyle/sneezing-back-pain-causes-remedy-12425854=" Whether it’s the common cold or a reaction to dust or temperature change
column2: sneezing is something we all do almost on a daily basis. But for those who have felt spasms of pain grip their back after a big
column3: sinus-clearing ah-choo
column4: they’d know that sneezing is not to be sniffed at. In fact
column5: sneezing-related back pain is rather common. “We see around 10 to 20 patients a week who complain of back pain and/or shooting pain in the lower limb following sneezing or while stifling a sneeze
column6: ” said Dr Reuben Soh
column7: a senior consultant with Singapore General Hospital’s Department of Orthopaedic Surgery. Dr Soh added that these patients are often “between 20 and 50 years old”. Furthermore
column8: the odds of throwing your back out isn’t something that exacerbates with age
column9: according to Adjunct Assistant Professor Jacob Oh
column10: the head of spine surgery and senior consultant with the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH).   In other words
column11: you don’t have to hit old age to run the risk; it may happen at any time. “As far as I am aware
column12: there is no major study that has shown that age increases the risk of sneezing-related back problems
column13: ” said Dr Oh. WHAT’S CAUSING THE PAIN? Sneezing is actually a very forceful action that causes your core muscles to tense up very suddenly
column14: said Dr Oh. At the same time
column15: the intervertebral discs
column16: which are like shock absorbers in your spine
column17: help to cushion the impact. Each intervertebral disc consists of the annulus fibrosus
column18: a sturdy
column19: tyre-like structure that encases a gel-like centre known as the nucleus pulposus. We see around 10 to 20 patients a week who complain of back pain and/or shooting pain in the lower limb following sneezing or while stifling a sneeze. But these shock absorbers can get busted if the sneeze is very forceful and repetitive
column20: resulting in a herniated disc
column21: said Dr Oh. A herniated disc is when the nucleus pulposus gets squeezed out of the annulus fibrosus and bulges into the spinal canal. This
column22: in turn
column23: can cause sciatica
column24: which refers to the numbness or pain shooting down your leg. In some patients
column25: said Dr Soh
column26: the force from sneezing may even tear the annulus fibrosus. WHO IS PRONE TO SNEEZE-RELATED BACK PAIN? For those below the age of 50
column27: sneezing may cause you to throw your back out if you’ve had a previous back injury
column28: said Dr Soh. Similarly
column29: you may be more prone if you used to do high-impact activities such as lifting heavy weights in the gym
column30: or sports with repetitive actions such as tennis or competitive rowing. Dr Soh added that smoking and being obese are other contributing factors.   SHOULD YOU BRACE YOUR BACK BEFORE YOU SNEEZE? There is no need to brace or tense your body
column31: said Ringo Yee
column32: the principal physiotherapist from TTSH’s Department of Physiotherapy. But straighten your body from a twisted or forward-bending position if you’re able to react in time
column34: try to adopt a neutral upright posture. Why is a forward-bending position bad for your back when you sneeze? “Sneezing builds up to 3.5 times the normal pressure in the discs compared to lying down
column35: ” said Dr Soh. Thus
column36: bending forward while sneezing easily exerts a greater force on the discs
column37: which can increase the risk of tearing the annulus fibrosus and herniating a disc. SHOULD YOU STIFLE YOUR SNEEZE? You shouldn’t. A healthy 34-year-old man did that and ended up busting his throat. The incident
column38: which was reported in the medical journal BMJ Case Reports in 2018
column39: mentioned that the unnamed patient tried to stop a sneeze by “pinching the nose and holding his mouth closed”.   Bad move because shortly after
column40: his throat hurt when he swallowed and there was a “change of voice”. What’s more
column41: his neck was swollen and when he moved it
column42: there was an unsettling popping and crackling sensation. As it turned out
column43: the patient had subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum. X-rays taken showed that the air that would have blasted from his nose and mouth made its way into the soft tissues of his neck instead. Sneezing builds up to 3.5 times the normal pressure in the discs compared to lying down. The man recovered in a week or so
column44: and continued to be well after a two-month follow-up. But can it happen to you? “This is rare in the context of the number of sneezes that happen on a daily basis all over the world
column45: ” said Dr Stephen Lee
column46: a consultant and Ear
column47: Nose and Throat (ENT) surgeon with Raffles Hospital. “If you are just trying to lessen the loudness of your sneeze
column48: it should not be harmful. But you do not want to totally suppress a sneeze as the sneeze is a defensive reflex to expel foreign particles from the upper airway
column49: ” said Dr Lee. I’VE BUSTED MY BACK FROM SNEEZING – WHAT NOW? Don’t panic
column50: said Yee. “Gently try and get back to a neutral sitting or standing position
column51: depending on what you were doing at the time of sneeze. See if you are able to move with relative ease.” If the pain persists beyond the sneeze
column52: take note of where it is. You might also want to take it easy that day
column53: meaning stay off vigorous physical activities
column54: Yee advised.   However
column55: that doesn’t give you the licence to lie in bed and do nothing. “Try and resume your daily activities as much as tolerated over the next few days. Most people recover from their low back pain episodes
column56: so take comfort in that thought
column58: consult your general practitioner for some short-term pain relief. “It usually takes one to two weeks to recover
column59: ” said Dr Soh. “But for patients with poor core strength
column60: it can take up to six weeks for the pain to subside. In cases of an annular tear
column61: healing usually occurs naturally between six weeks and three months.” Yee added that if the pain is severe and lasts beyond four weeks
column62: you might want to check in with a specialist. “In rare situations
column63: consult a doctor early if there are symptoms of weakness in the legs
column64: or loss of control of the bladder or bowel

column1: No extra restrictions on import of face masks
column2: hand sanitisers; usual GST rules apply: Customs=17 Feb 2020 04:19PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 04:20PM)=CNA/hz(aj)=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid19-coronavirus-no-extra-restrictions-face-masks-gst-customs-12441830=" SINGAPORE: No extra restrictions have been imposed on face masks and hand sanitisers brought into Singapore
column3: the Singapore Customs said on Monday (Feb 17). "No additional Customs restrictions have been imposed on the import of face masks and hand sanitisers
column4: a spokesperson said in response to queries by CNA. As with all goods brought into Singapore
column5: travellers are required to declare and pay Goods and Services Tax (GST) if the total value of goods imported for personal use exceeds the GST import relief
column6: or the goods are for commercial purposes." The response comes after an image circulating on social media showed a sign put up by the Singapore Customs requesting that travellers who enter the country declare "all face masks and sanitisers"
column7: alongside other dutiable items such as tobacco
column8: cigarettes and alcohol.  The Customs spokesperson clarified that the sign depicted in the Facebook post was put up at the Singapore Cruise Centre in response to a "surge in the number of ferry passengers hand-carrying sizeable quantities of surgical masks and hand sanitisers into Singapore". "As a number of travellers had quantities of masks and sanitisers with values in excess of their GST import relief thresholds or which were for commercial purposes
column9: they were stopped at the baggage screening area and turned back to the Customs service counters for GST payment
column10: the spokesperson added. The sign was therefore put up with good intentions by our frontline staff to remind travellers to make their GST payments first before proceeding for customs clearance
column11: so as to minimise inconvenience and help expedite their clearance at the Singapore Cruise Centre. "Unfortunately
column12: the intent was misconstrued." The Customs spokesperson said that the sign was put up only at the cruise centre to address a specific situation
column13: and that the other checkpoints do not have similar signs. Singapore has seen a surge in demand for face masks amid concern over the novel coronavirus. Some retailers have raised the prices of masks drastically
column14: while private sellers have taken to selling boxes of face masks online
column15: usually in bulk. The authorities have repeatedly stressed that Singapore has sufficient masks in its stockpile
column16: and sent letters of demand asking several retailers to explain their pricing strategy for masks.  Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: 5 COVID-19 patients in Singapore discharged from hospital
column2: 2 new cases reported=17 Feb 2020 08:04PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 08:25PM)=CNA/hs=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid19-coronavirus-singapore-update-feb-17-12441176=" SINGAPORE: Five more COVID-19 patients in Singapore have been discharged from hospital
column3: said the Ministry of Health (MOH) in a daily update on Monday (Feb 17). In all
column4: 24 cases have fully recovered from the infection and have been discharged from hospital. Two new COVID-19 cases were also reported on Monday
column5: bringing the total number of confirmed cases in Singapore to 77. Case 76 is a one-year-old Singaporean who was among the group evacuated from Wuhan on Feb 9. The toddler was without symptoms when he boarded the flight back to Singapore. He was put under quarantine upon landing in Singapore
column6: and was confirmed to be infected with COVID-19 on Sunday afternoon. He is currently warded in an isolation room at KK Women's and Children's Hospital
column7: said MOH. "All Singaporeans evacuated from Wuhan were tested for COVID-19 as an added precaution
column8: MOH said. Case 77 is a 35-year-old Singaporean man who has no recent travel history to China. He is a close contact of Case 50, a 62-year-old Singaporean who works at DBS. The 35-year-old was tested positive for the infection on Monday morning and is currently warded at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID).    Singapore raised its Disease Outbreak Response System Condition (DORSCON) level to Orange on Feb 7, prompting additional precautionary measures. Earlier on Monday, MOH announced a new Stay-Home Notice for Singapore residents and long-term pass holders with recent travel history to mainland China outside the Hubei province. From Tuesday, such travellers will be required to stay home at all times during their 14-day leave period. This is stricter than the Leave of Absence measure currently in place, which allows them to leave their homes briefly, for example for meals or to buy household supplies. COVID-19 has killed more than 1,700 and infected more than 70,500 in mainland China. It has spread to more than 25 countries, including Singapore, Japan and Thailand. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the novel coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram

column1: COVID-19: New Stay-Home Notice with stricter measures for Singapore residents
column2: long-term pass holders returning from mainland China=17 Feb 2020 05:34PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 06:30PM)=CNA/hs(mi)=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid19-coronavirus-stay-at-home-leave-china-singapore-12442116=" SINGAPORE: The Ministry of Health (MOH) on Monday (Feb 17) announced a new Stay-Home Notice (SHN) for Singapore residents and long-term pass holders returning to Singapore from mainland China. As part of the notice requirements
column3: such travellers will have to remain in their homes at all times during the 14-day leave period. This is stricter than the Leave of Absence (LOA) currently in place
column4: which allows them to leave their homes briefly
column5: for example to have their meals or buy household supplies. The SHN will take effect from 11.59pm on Tuesday and will apply to all returnees with recent travel history to China (outside Hubei) within the last 14 days.  With the implementation of the SHN
column6: the Government will no longer be issuing LOAs to such returnees
column7: the health ministry said. "The vast majority on the present regime would have served out their LOAs in the coming days and we will continue to ensure their compliance in the meantime
column8: said MOH. The SHN will also cover returning workers from mainland China on work passes. For such workers
column9: we already require employers to seek prior approval from the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) before they travel to Singapore. If employers need help
column10: MOM will link them up with hotels or dormitory operators for their workers to serve out the SHN
column11: said the health ministry. MOH said the implementation of the SHN is another precautionary measure we are taking to minimise the risk of additional imported cases of COVID-19". Similar to those placed on LOA
column12: these travellers are not suspected to have been in close contact with confirmed cases of COVID-19 infection
column13: nor are they unwell or display symptoms of the virus. "These individuals are bearing inconvenience for the benefit of the wider community
column14: said MOH. We therefore urge all landlords to cooperate and to allow their tenants who are placed on SHN to serve out their full-14 day requirements
column15: it added. The Government said it would continue to implement surveillance and enforcement measures to ensure compliance to the SHN requirements. There will also be support for those who need help during their SHN period, for example access to food and other daily necessities. Singapore citizens, permanent residents and long-term visit pass holders can seek help from the People's Association. Students can get help from their schools or institutions, or the Ministry of Education. Those on work passes can look for their employers or MOM. 1,200 PEOPLE ON QUARANTINE: LAWRENCE WONG Speaking to reporters on Monday, Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong said that there are 1,200 people on quarantine to date. About half of them are in Government quarantine facilities, while the rest are quarantined at home.  The SHN is similar to the Home Quarantine Order, with differences in the requirements for physical isolation. The quarantine order is served to people who have come into close contact with individuals who have been infected, while those serving the SHN are not suspected to have had such exposure. Those under the Home Quarantine Order need to be separated from other people within the home"
column16: said Mr Wong. In comparison
column17: the SHN allows people to share a room with their family members
column18: he added. However
column19: Mr Wong said those who live under one roof with family members under the SHN could practice "common sense" and good hygiene when it comes to preparing food and the use of common utensils. Responding to a question
column20: Mr Wong also said that visits from outsiders were discouraged
column21: but if close family members wanted to visit individuals placed under the SHN
column22: they should take "some precautions". The main requirement is that those served with the SHN do not leave their homes
column23: he added. Long-term pass holders will have their passes revoked if they flout the rules of the SNH
column24: while Singaporeans and permanent residents may face prosecution under the Infectious Diseases Act
column25: said Mr Wong. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the novel coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: COVID-19 threat could erode with time just as with H1N1
column2: say experts=17 Feb 2020 06:14AM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 08:05AM)=CNA/hw=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid-19-threat-could-erode-with-time-just-as-with-h1n1-say-12438600=" SINGAPORE: The outbreak of COVID-19 infections that started in Wuhan
column3: China and has now spread to almost 30 other countries including Singapore could follow the same trajectory seen in the H1N1 influenza outbreak in Mexico just over a decade ago. It could fade into something less sinister later on
column4: said infectious disease experts. In early March 2009
column5: Mexico experienced outbreaks of respiratory illness and increased reports of patients with flu-like symptoms in several areas of the country. This new human H1N1 strain
column6: which originated from swine flu in pigs
column7: swept across the world and by the World Health Organization's (WHO) estimate
column8: was responsible for more than 18
column9: 000 deaths globally in the 2009 pandemic. JUST ANOTHER FLU BUG WHO declared the virus a public health emergency on Apr 24
column10: 2009. Four days later
column11: Singapore raised its Disease Outbreak Response (DORSCON) from Green to Yellow. This was raised to Orange on Apr 30
column12: when the WHO raised its pandemic alert level from phase 4 to phase 5. But it was not until May 26
column13: 2009 that Singapore saw its first case of H1N1
column14: 15 days after the Ministry of Health (MOH) revised the DORSCON alert back down to Yellow. A 22-year-old undergraduate returning from New York had developed symptoms on the flight and later tested positive for the virus. The outbreak in Singapore peaked in Aug 2009
column15: and the country saw 18 H1N1 fatalities in that year. By the time the DORSCON alert was lowered from yellow to green on Feb 21
column17: about 415
column18: 000 people islandwide had been infected with the virus
column19: with most experiencing mild illness. “Everyone then realised that it was just another flu bug. The initial deaths in Mexico were not seen in Singapore. Very surprising
column20: ” said Dr Leong Hoe Nam
column21: an infectious disease specialist at Mount Elizabeth Novena Hospital. “Now when you revisit Mexico
column22: the same virus circulates there
column23: but it doesn’t kill that much.” This is because the threat of H1N1 eroded over the years
column24: he added. And the same is likely to happen for COVID-19
column25: said experts CNA spoke to. VIRUSES BECOME MILDER OVER TIME: EXPERTS Professor Tikki Pang
column26: visiting professor at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy under the National University of Singapore (NUS) said the coronavirus causing the COVID-19 outbreak is likely to stabilise and eventually disappear from public consciousness. “This is the historical pattern of past pandemics
column27: and happens because the virus ‘burns out’ and runs out of people to infect as a result of many factors
column28: ” said Prof Pang
column29: citing warmer temperatures
column30: better public awareness and public health measures. “There is a possibility that the virus could mutate into something more ‘sinister’
column31: (that) spreads faster (or causes) more severe disease
column34: we have not seen any evidence of this happening.” According to Dr Leong
column35: there are four circulating coronaviruses that cause the common cold
column36: and one of them periodically causes severe pneumonia. “I believe they came into existence much like the current COVID-19. It killed many people and virology or technology was not sufficiently established then to identify the cause of the illness. But it became attenuated with time
column37: ” said Dr Leong. “COVID-19 will go the same way. What we need is time for it to accumulate mutations
column38: and it will become milder.” According to Dr Leong
column39: there is a “natural tendency” for viruses to mutate to something milder. If the virus is too pathogenic and it kills its host
column40: it is unable to continue spreading. But if it is mild
column41: it can continue to propagate and pass on to other individuals
column42: eventually picking up mutations that reduce the virus' ability to cause disease
column43: said Dr Leong. He noted that increasing awareness of H1N1 treatment and availability of vaccines also contributed to the threat fading. According to experts
column44: H1N1 is currently a dominant flu strain in Singapore
column45: although this may vary between seasons
column46: and flu vaccines provide immunity against it. Countries in the region face a similar situation - Taiwan's Centre for Disease Control said earlier this month that 56 patients there had died of H1N1 flu virus-affected respiratory failure in the past three months. In the years following the 2009 pandemic
column48: but has been on the increase in recent years
column49: said Professor Clarence Tam from the Saw Swee Hock School of Public Health
column50: NUS. "This is likely because
column51: after the pandemic
column52: many people were infected with H1N1 and developed immunity against this influenza strain
column53: so the virus couldn't spread as easily
column54: said Prof Tam. But we know that immunity against influenza is short-lived
column55: and as the level of immunity drops in the population
column56: more people are now becoming infected with this strain again." Dr Leong said: “It becomes another flu bug. And it helps with the fact that Singaporeans cannot distinguish between flu and the common cold
column57: making the concept of flu in Singapore much milder. “People soon became complacent of H1N1. But
column58: some lethality maintained. If there is a bad case of influenza in the intensive care (unit)
column59: it would usually be a H1N1 (case). But overall
column60: we see less and less of a problem.” TRANSMISSION OF COVID-19
column61: H1N1 SIMILAR Speaking at a press conference on Friday (Feb 14)
column62: Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong had said that it is “clearly emerging” that COVID-19 is different from Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) and has more similarities with H1N1. “The transmission mechanism of COVID-19 is different from SARS. In fact
column63: the transmission mechanism is closer to H1N1 or influenza
column64: ” said Mr Wong. Researchers at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) have confirmed this
column67: COVID-19 is infectious when symptoms are mild. Because of this transmission mechanism
column70: can spread “quite quickly”
column71: said Mr Wong. “With our mild symptoms
column72: we sometimes let our guard down - we continue going out even though we don’t really feel well
column73: and that’s how the virus transmits
column74: ” he added. Mr Wong also said it was “a matter of time” before “a lot of people around the world” will be infected with COVID-19. Citing the widespread community transmission seen in the 2009 H1N1 pandemic
column75: Mr Wong said: “We’re not saying that this will happen for COVID-19. It’s a different disease than H1N1 so the patterns of transmission and the number of people contracting the disease will be different
column76: ” he said. "But because the transmission patterns are similar to H1N1
column77: we should be prepared for a scenario where you get wider transmission around the world.” Prof Tam stressed that even if the risk of mortality from a virus is low
column78: it can still cause a large number of deaths if it spreads easily
column79: citing the current COVID-19 outbreak as an example. “The available data indicate that this new virus is not as deadly as SARS
column80: but spreads much more readily from person to person. Consequently
column81: the number of reported deaths has already surpassed deaths from SARS in less than two months
column82: ” he said. “The same applies for influenza viruses. Even though the proportion of all influenza cases that succumb to the disease is low
column85: 000 people worldwide die each year from influenza.” Adding that it is “difficult to predict” whether the COVID-19 will take the same route as the H1N1 pandemic
column86: Prof Tam said: “The concern is that if current efforts to contain the virus aren’t ultimately enough to stamp out human transmission
column87: it could spread rapidly across the globe causing many more hospitalisations and deaths before a vaccine can be developed or enough immunity builds up in the population to bring the epidemic under control.” Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: Singapore cuts 2020 GDP forecast range to -0.5% to 1.5% due to COVID-19 outbreak=17 Feb 2020 08:11AM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 02:25PM)=CNA/mn=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/singapore-cuts-2020-gdp-forecast-covid-19-economy-12440764=" SINGAPORE: After seeing its economy grow at a decade-low of 0.7 per cent last year
column2: Singapore is expecting possibly even slower growth in 2020 and has downgraded its gross domestic product (GDP) forecast amid concerns about the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak. Economic growth for this year is expected to come in at around 0.5 per cent
column3: the mid-point of a new estimated range of between -0.5 per cent and 1.5 per cent
column4: said the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) on Monday (Feb 17). The previous forecast range announced last November was 0.5 per cent to 2.5 per cent. Singapore has so far confirmed 75 cases of the novel coronavirus
column5: with authorities earlier this month raising the Disease Outbreak Response System Condition (DORSCON) to Orange. Last week
column6: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak will have a significant impact on the local economy for the next couple of quarters. MTI said its earlier forecast was premised on a modest pick-up in global growth and a recovery in the global electronics cycle this year. However
column7: the outbreak of COVID-19 has affected many countries around the world
column8: including Singapore
column9: and is likely to dampen the growth prospects of China and those impacted. In China
column10: GDP growth in 2020 will likely come in lower than earlier projected due to a pullback in household consumption as a result of the lockdowns and travel restrictions implemented in several major Chinese cities to contain the spread of the novel coronavirus
column11: it said. Industrial production has also been disrupted due to work stoppages and delays arising from these containment measures
column12: MTI noted in its report. These will
column13: in turn
column14: have a knock-on impact on regional economies through lower outbound tourism and other import demand from China
column15: as well as disruptions to supply chains
column16: it added. “Should the COVID-19 outbreak be more widespread
column17: severe and protracted than anticipated
column18: there could be a sharper pullback in global consumption
column19: as well as more prolonged disruptions to global supply chains and production
column20: ” the report said. MTI also cautioned that a sharper-than-expected economic slowdown in China due to the virus outbreak will negatively affect global trade and economic growth. At the same time
column21: other uncertainties in the global economy remain
column22: such as the US-China trade war and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East
column23: it added. As a result
column24: the outlook for the Singapore economy has weakened since its last review in November
column25: the ministry said
column26: adding that the ongoing COVID-19 situation could impact the local economy through several channels. First
column27: the outward-oriented sectors
column28: such as manufacturing and wholesale trade
column29: will be affected by the weaker growth outlook in several of Singapore’s key final demand markets
column30: including China. Firms in these sectors could also be affected by supply chain disruptions arising from prolonged factory closures and labour shortages in China. Second
column31: there has been a sharp fall in tourist arrivals
column33: and this has badly affected the local tourism and transport sectors. Third
column34: domestic consumption is likely to decline as locals cut back on shopping and dining-out activities. This will adversely affect firms in segments such as retail and food services
column35: the ministry noted. MTI permanent secretary Gabriel Lim said at a press conference that the hit on GDP growth is likely to be felt during the first two quarters of the year
column36: although the impact through these three channels could play out further down the road and will need to be closely watched. The ministry emphasised that while its latest GDP forecast range includes the possibility of a recession
column37: that is not its central scenario and its baseline view is for the economy to see positive growth at around 0.5 per cent for 2020. “As the COVID-19 situation is still evolving
column38: there is a significant degree of uncertainty over the length and severity of the outbreak
column39: and hence its overall impact on the Singapore economy
column40: ” Mr Lim said. “MTI will continue to monitor developments and their impact on the Singapore economy closely.” The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said its monetary policy remains unchanged
column41: as it had highlighted in a statement earlier this month. The central bank is monitoring developments very closely and its next policy review remains as scheduled in April
column42: its deputy managing director Edward Robinson told reporters. 2019 GROWTH SLOWEST IN A DECADE MTI’s report on Monday also showed the Singapore economy expanded by 1 per cent year-on-year in the last quarter of 2019
column43: slightly above the Government’s initial estimate of 0.8 per cent and the 0.7 per cent growth in the earlier quarter. On a quarter-on-quarter seasonally adjusted annualised basis
column44: growth came in at 0.6 per cent. This is way below the 2.2 per cent expansion in the third quarter
column45: but above the 0.1 per cent flash estimate. This brings the full-year growth in 2019 to 0.7 per cent
column46: a sharp slowdown from 2018’s 3.4 per cent and hitting the country’s lowest growth since the global financial crisis in 2009. The manufacturing sector was the biggest laggard last year. It contracted by 1.4 per cent
column48: due to output declines in the electronics
column49: chemicals
column50: precision engineering and transport engineering clusters. Construction expanded by 2.8 per cent
column51: turning around from the 3.5 per cent contraction in 2018
column52: supported by both public sector and private sector construction works. The services producing industries also grew by 1.1 per cent
column53: albeit moderating from the 3.4 per cent growth in 2018. Growth largely came from the finance and insurance
column54: other services and business services sectors. For this year
column55: there are still expectations for a “modest growth” in the manufacturing sector
column56: although authorities are closely watching for the impact of COVID-19 on clusters
column58: which have been showing some signs of a tentative rebound
column59: said Economic Development Board’s assistant managing director Kelvin Wong. There are also pockets of relative strength in the Singapore economy
column60: such as the construction sector which is projected to post steady growth given the rebound in construction demand since 2018. The information and communications sector is also expected to be resilient on account of sustained enterprise demand for IT solutions
column61: MTI said. ALL EYES ON “STRONG” BUDGET 2020 Given how the economy is likely to feel the strain from the flu-like virus
column62: economists say a “strong” relief package will likely be announced on Tuesday as part of the Budget
column63: as the Government had promised. Maybank Kim Eng economists
column64: for instance
column65: are pencilling help of at least S$700 million – way higher than the S$230 million relief package released during 2003’s severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreak. Measures to support the hardest-hit sectors may range from tax rebates for commercial
column67: lower foreign worker levies for tourism-related sectors to bridging loans for smaller firms. The two integrated resorts
column70: the economists said. DBS senior economist Irvin Seah is expecting the Government to put forth an overall deficit of about S$7.9 billion in Budget 2020
column71: the biggest in a decade. “A strong fiscal response is expected to mitigate the impact of the virus outbreak
column72: ” he wrote in a note. OCBC Bank head of treasury research and strategy Selena Ling also expects an overall budget deficit of about S$8 billion
column73: which will include a “sizeable COVID-19 relief package and a GST offset package”. And if the deadly virus chills growth further
column74: monetary policy easing will likely be on the cards. Ms Ling said: “Policymakers are also cognizant of the downside growth risks so a strong Budget response and/or monetary policy response in April may help to mitigate and cushion some of the downside risks. “At this juncture
column75: we do not rule out the possibility of the MAS reverting to a zero appreciation path for the S$NEER (Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate) and regard a re-centering lower as the lower-probability event
column76: ” she added. Separately on Monday
column77: Enterprise Singapore cut its 2020 forecasts for non-oil domestic exports (NODX) and total merchandise trade
column78: citing likely impact of the novel coronavirus outbreak on its trading partners and lower oil prices. Both NODX and total merchandise are now expected to come in between -0.5 per cent to 1.5 per cent this year
column79: down from an earlier projection of zero to 2 per cent growth. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the Wuhan virus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: China coronavirus death toll surpasses 1
column2: 700; decline in new cases outside Hubei=17 Feb 2020 07:29AM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 09:46AM)=Agencies/mn=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/china-covid-19-coronavirus-wuhan-virus-hubei-new-cases-12440692=" BEIJING: The death toll from China's new coronavirus epidemic jumped to 1
column3: 770 after 105 more people died
column4: the National Health Commission said on Monday (Feb 17). More than 70
column5: 500 have now been infected nationwide by the virus
column6: which first emerged in December in central Hubei province before spreading across the country. Chinese authorities have placed about 56 million people in Hubei and its capital Wuhan under quarantine
column7: virtually sealing off the province from the rest of the country in an unprecedented effort to contain the virus. New cases outside of the epicentre have been declining for the last 13 days. There were 115 fresh cases outside the central province
column8: according to the commission on Monday - sharply down from nearly 450 a week ago. Local authorities elsewhere in China have introduced measures to try and stop the virus spreading
column9: including a rule in Beijing requiring people coming to the capital to self-quarantine for 14 days
column10: according to official media. Most cases are still in Hubei
column11: where nearly 2
column12: 000 were reported on Monday.   The number of reported infections ballooned on Thursday last week after Hubei authorities changed their criteria for counting cases
column13: retroactively adding 14
column14: 000 cases in a single day. Monday's figures for new cases were around 100 higher than those on Sunday but still sharply down on those from Friday and Saturday. A spokesman for China's national health authority said that the slowdown was a sign the outbreak was being controlled. However
column15: World Health Organization chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has warned it is "impossible to predict which direction this epidemic will take". International experts have arrived in Beijing and begun meeting with their Chinese counterparts over the epidemic
column16: Tedros said on Twitter. Outside mainland China
column17: Taipei officials reported the island's first death from the new coronavirus on Sunday
column18: as a 61-year-old man from central Taiwan with underlying health problems but no recent overseas travel history died in hospital. He is the fifth person outside of the mainland to die from the virus
column19: with the other deaths in the Philippines
column20: Hong Kong
column21: Japan and France. The biggest cluster outside China is on a quarantined cruise ship outside Japan with 356 infections confirmed
column22: including a quarantine officer. A top US health official on Sunday said 40 Americans from the ship have become infected and would be treated in Japan. Other Americans left the Diamond Princess into the early hours of Monday for chartered jets that would fly them home - and into further quarantine. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the COVID-19 outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: 14 test positive among US plane evacuees from Japan cruise ship=17 Feb 2020 03:28PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 06:12PM)=AFP/hs=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/covid-19-diamond-princess-14-evacuees-infected-united-states-12441826=" WASHINGTON: Fourteen people who had tested positive for the new coronavirus were among more than 300 US citizens and family members evacuated by plane from a quarantined ship in Japan
column2: the US State Department said Monday (Feb 17). The passengers had already disembarked from the Diamond Princess and were preparing to return to the United States on chartered aircraft when US officials were informed 14 of them who had been tested days earlier were positive for COVID-19
column3: it said in a joint statement with the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). After consultation with HHS
column4: the State Department decided to allow them on board
column5: but isolated them from the other passengers. "These individuals were moved in the most expeditious and safe manner to a specialised containment area on the evacuation aircraft to isolate them in accordance with standard protocols
column6: it said. During the flights
column7: these individuals will continue to be isolated from the other passengers." All passengers were being closely monitored throughout the flights. "Any who become symptomatic will be moved to the specialised containment area
column8: where they will be treated
column9: the statement said. The first flight is due to land shortly at a US Air Force base in California, where all passengers will undergo a 14-day quarantine, while a second plane is heading to another base in San Antonio, Texas. Another 99 people have tested positive for coronavirus on a cruise ship off the Japan coast, Japanese media said Monday, citing new figures from the health ministry. That would take the total number of positive cases on the Diamond Princess to 454. The health ministry declined to confirm the reports immediately. More than 600 people are already in quarantine in the United States, evacuated earlier from the virus epicentre in the Chinese city of Wuhan, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Friday. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram

column1: HipVan employee with COVID-19 had close contact with 3 colleagues
column2: stayed home after developing symptoms=17 Feb 2020 06:31PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 06:40PM)=CNA/hw(hm)=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/coronavirus-hipvan-employee-covid19-colleague-quarantine-case-70-12442098=" SINGAPORE: A 27-year-old Singaporean woman who was confirmed as Singapore’s 70th case of COVID-19 on Saturday (Feb 15) had close contact with three colleagues
column3: but did not go to work after developing symptoms
column4: said her employer HipVan. The patient is a full-time employee in HipVan’s merchandising department
column5: a HipVan spokesperson said. According to the Ministry of Health (MOH)
column6: she went to the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) on Feb 14
column7: after seeking treatment at a general practitioner clinic on Feb 3. She had flu-like symptoms from Feb 3 to Feb 7
column8: and was on medical leave that week
column9: said the HipVan spokesperson in response to CNA queries. The patient went back to work from Feb 10 to Feb 12 after recovering and did not exhibit any symptoms. But she felt unwell again on Feb 13 and was told to work from home. She did not come in to work after that
column10: said the spokesperson. The patient did not have any close contact with any clients or partners in the last two weeks
column11: but did have close contact with three colleagues who are now under home quarantine
