column15: World Health Organization chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has warned it is "impossible to predict which direction this epidemic will take". International experts have arrived in Beijing and begun meeting with their Chinese counterparts over the epidemic
column16: Tedros said on Twitter. Outside mainland China
column17: Taipei officials reported the island's first death from the new coronavirus on Sunday
column18: as a 61-year-old man from central Taiwan with underlying health problems but no recent overseas travel history died in hospital. He is the fifth person outside of the mainland to die from the virus
column19: with the other deaths in the Philippines
column20: Hong Kong
column21: Japan and France. The biggest cluster outside China is on a quarantined cruise ship outside Japan with 356 infections confirmed
column22: including a quarantine officer. A top US health official on Sunday said 40 Americans from the ship have become infected and would be treated in Japan. Other Americans left the Diamond Princess into the early hours of Monday for chartered jets that would fly them home - and into further quarantine. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the COVID-19 outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: 14 test positive among US plane evacuees from Japan cruise ship=17 Feb 2020 03:28PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 06:12PM)=AFP/hs=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/covid-19-diamond-princess-14-evacuees-infected-united-states-12441826=" WASHINGTON: Fourteen people who had tested positive for the new coronavirus were among more than 300 US citizens and family members evacuated by plane from a quarantined ship in Japan
column2: the US State Department said Monday (Feb 17). The passengers had already disembarked from the Diamond Princess and were preparing to return to the United States on chartered aircraft when US officials were informed 14 of them who had been tested days earlier were positive for COVID-19
column3: it said in a joint statement with the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). After consultation with HHS
column4: the State Department decided to allow them on board
column5: but isolated them from the other passengers. "These individuals were moved in the most expeditious and safe manner to a specialised containment area on the evacuation aircraft to isolate them in accordance with standard protocols
column6: it said. During the flights
column7: these individuals will continue to be isolated from the other passengers." All passengers were being closely monitored throughout the flights. "Any who become symptomatic will be moved to the specialised containment area
column8: where they will be treated
column9: the statement said. The first flight is due to land shortly at a US Air Force base in California, where all passengers will undergo a 14-day quarantine, while a second plane is heading to another base in San Antonio, Texas. Another 99 people have tested positive for coronavirus on a cruise ship off the Japan coast, Japanese media said Monday, citing new figures from the health ministry. That would take the total number of positive cases on the Diamond Princess to 454. The health ministry declined to confirm the reports immediately. More than 600 people are already in quarantine in the United States, evacuated earlier from the virus epicentre in the Chinese city of Wuhan, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Friday. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram

column1: HipVan employee with COVID-19 had close contact with 3 colleagues
column2: stayed home after developing symptoms=17 Feb 2020 06:31PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 06:40PM)=CNA/hw(hm)=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/coronavirus-hipvan-employee-covid19-colleague-quarantine-case-70-12442098=" SINGAPORE: A 27-year-old Singaporean woman who was confirmed as Singapore’s 70th case of COVID-19 on Saturday (Feb 15) had close contact with three colleagues
column3: but did not go to work after developing symptoms
column4: said her employer HipVan. The patient is a full-time employee in HipVan’s merchandising department
column5: a HipVan spokesperson said. According to the Ministry of Health (MOH)
column6: she went to the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) on Feb 14
column7: after seeking treatment at a general practitioner clinic on Feb 3. She had flu-like symptoms from Feb 3 to Feb 7
column8: and was on medical leave that week
column9: said the HipVan spokesperson in response to CNA queries. The patient went back to work from Feb 10 to Feb 12 after recovering and did not exhibit any symptoms. But she felt unwell again on Feb 13 and was told to work from home. She did not come in to work after that
column10: said the spokesperson. The patient did not have any close contact with any clients or partners in the last two weeks
column11: but did have close contact with three colleagues who are now under home quarantine
column12: the spokesperson added. The three other employees have also been advised by MOH to take the necessary precautions to limit contact with their families
column13: she said. “Besides the three colleagues that have close contact with the patient
column14: our management team has also taken additional precautionary measures by getting all the staff that work from our Kallang office to work from home until further notice
column15: ” said the spokesperson. “We are also currently assisting MOH personnel with daily phone monitoring of all of our staff and so far
column16: no other staff has tested positive for the COVID-19 virus.” HipVan said it will also be working with the Health Ministry to disinfect its Kallang office and close its showroom to visitors until disinfection has been completed. “In addition
column17: we would also like the public to know that our warehouse and delivery teams
column18: managed by third-party service providers
column19: work out of a different location in Tuas
column20: and have had no close contact with the patient in the past weeks
column21: ” said the spokesperson.   The patient
column22: Case 70
column23: is a family member of Case 66
column24: linked to the Grace Assembly of God cluster. She stays at Mei Hwan Drive and had attended church services at God’s Kingdom Bread of Life Church prior to hospital admission
column25: said MOH on Sunday. On Sunday
column26: Singapore confirmed three new cases of COVID-19
column27: including a Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) regular serviceman
column28: bringing the total number of cases here to 75. There have been 18 confirmed cases linked to the Grace Assembly of God cluster so far. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the novel coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"

column1: Thailand reports new coronavirus case
column2: to increase entry screening=17 Feb 2020 02:10PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 02:30PM)=Reuters/hs=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/covid19-thailand-new-coronavirus-case-35-12441616=" BANGKOK: Thailand said on Monday (Feb 17) it had recorded one new case of the coronavirus and was increasing screening of visitors from Singapore and Japan entering the country in response to the widening outbreak. The new case
column3: a 60-year-old Chinese woman whose family members earlier contracted the virus
column4: takes the total number of cases in Thailand to 35 since January
column5: Sukhum Kanchanapimai
column6: the health ministry's permanent secretary told a news conference. "This is the from an old case of a Chinese family of nine
column7: all of them have now been infected
column8: he said. Fifteen of the infected people in Thailand have recovered and returned home, while 20 are still being treated in hospital. Some 1,770 people in China have died from the virus, along with a handful in other countries and territories but Thailand has not recorded any fatalities so far. Thai health authorities said they will expand virus screening to cover travellers from Japan and Singapore, in addition to those from mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan. Japan and Singapore have two of the highest numbers of reported cases outside China. Anyone from those places who displays coronavirus symptoms will be quarantined at a government hospital. Travellers from Japan and Singapore that developed a fever or respiratory symptoms within 14 days of entering the country will be treated like travellers from China
column9: Sukhum said. In addition, Thailand will not allow entry by any foreign nationals who were passengers of the Westerdam cruise ship, now docked in Cambodia, after an American woman tested positive for coronavirus in Malaysia over the weekend. There were 21 Thai nationals on board the ship and health authorities said all of them will be quarantined for 14 days when they enter Thailand. Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram

column1: Did sneezing just give you back pain? It’s more common than you think=17 Feb 2020 06:30AM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 08:07AM)=CNA/bk=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/lifestyle/sneezing-back-pain-causes-remedy-12425854=" Whether it’s the common cold or a reaction to dust or temperature change
column2: sneezing is something we all do almost on a daily basis. But for those who have felt spasms of pain grip their back after a big
column3: sinus-clearing ah-choo
column4: they’d know that sneezing is not to be sniffed at. In fact
column5: sneezing-related back pain is rather common. “We see around 10 to 20 patients a week who complain of back pain and/or shooting pain in the lower limb following sneezing or while stifling a sneeze
column6: ” said Dr Reuben Soh
column7: a senior consultant with Singapore General Hospital’s Department of Orthopaedic Surgery. Dr Soh added that these patients are often “between 20 and 50 years old”. Furthermore
column8: the odds of throwing your back out isn’t something that exacerbates with age
column9: according to Adjunct Assistant Professor Jacob Oh
column10: the head of spine surgery and senior consultant with the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH).   In other words
column11: you don’t have to hit old age to run the risk; it may happen at any time. “As far as I am aware
column12: there is no major study that has shown that age increases the risk of sneezing-related back problems
column13: ” said Dr Oh. WHAT’S CAUSING THE PAIN? Sneezing is actually a very forceful action that causes your core muscles to tense up very suddenly
column14: said Dr Oh. At the same time
column15: the intervertebral discs
column16: which are like shock absorbers in your spine
column17: help to cushion the impact. Each intervertebral disc consists of the annulus fibrosus
column18: a sturdy
column19: tyre-like structure that encases a gel-like centre known as the nucleus pulposus. We see around 10 to 20 patients a week who complain of back pain and/or shooting pain in the lower limb following sneezing or while stifling a sneeze. But these shock absorbers can get busted if the sneeze is very forceful and repetitive
column20: resulting in a herniated disc
column21: said Dr Oh. A herniated disc is when the nucleus pulposus gets squeezed out of the annulus fibrosus and bulges into the spinal canal. This
column22: in turn
column23: can cause sciatica
column24: which refers to the numbness or pain shooting down your leg. In some patients
column25: said Dr Soh
column26: the force from sneezing may even tear the annulus fibrosus. WHO IS PRONE TO SNEEZE-RELATED BACK PAIN? For those below the age of 50
column27: sneezing may cause you to throw your back out if you’ve had a previous back injury
column28: said Dr Soh. Similarly
column29: you may be more prone if you used to do high-impact activities such as lifting heavy weights in the gym
column30: or sports with repetitive actions such as tennis or competitive rowing. Dr Soh added that smoking and being obese are other contributing factors.   SHOULD YOU BRACE YOUR BACK BEFORE YOU SNEEZE? There is no need to brace or tense your body
column31: said Ringo Yee
column32: the principal physiotherapist from TTSH’s Department of Physiotherapy. But straighten your body from a twisted or forward-bending position if you’re able to react in time
column34: try to adopt a neutral upright posture. Why is a forward-bending position bad for your back when you sneeze? “Sneezing builds up to 3.5 times the normal pressure in the discs compared to lying down
column35: ” said Dr Soh. Thus
column36: bending forward while sneezing easily exerts a greater force on the discs
column37: which can increase the risk of tearing the annulus fibrosus and herniating a disc. SHOULD YOU STIFLE YOUR SNEEZE? You shouldn’t. A healthy 34-year-old man did that and ended up busting his throat. The incident
column38: which was reported in the medical journal BMJ Case Reports in 2018
column39: mentioned that the unnamed patient tried to stop a sneeze by “pinching the nose and holding his mouth closed”.   Bad move because shortly after
column40: his throat hurt when he swallowed and there was a “change of voice”. What’s more
column41: his neck was swollen and when he moved it
column42: there was an unsettling popping and crackling sensation. As it turned out
column43: the patient had subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum. X-rays taken showed that the air that would have blasted from his nose and mouth made its way into the soft tissues of his neck instead. Sneezing builds up to 3.5 times the normal pressure in the discs compared to lying down. The man recovered in a week or so
column44: and continued to be well after a two-month follow-up. But can it happen to you? “This is rare in the context of the number of sneezes that happen on a daily basis all over the world
column45: ” said Dr Stephen Lee
column46: a consultant and Ear
column47: Nose and Throat (ENT) surgeon with Raffles Hospital. “If you are just trying to lessen the loudness of your sneeze
column48: it should not be harmful. But you do not want to totally suppress a sneeze as the sneeze is a defensive reflex to expel foreign particles from the upper airway
column49: ” said Dr Lee. I’VE BUSTED MY BACK FROM SNEEZING – WHAT NOW? Don’t panic
column50: said Yee. “Gently try and get back to a neutral sitting or standing position
column51: depending on what you were doing at the time of sneeze. See if you are able to move with relative ease.” If the pain persists beyond the sneeze
column52: take note of where it is. You might also want to take it easy that day
column53: meaning stay off vigorous physical activities
column54: Yee advised.   However
column55: that doesn’t give you the licence to lie in bed and do nothing. “Try and resume your daily activities as much as tolerated over the next few days. Most people recover from their low back pain episodes
column56: so take comfort in that thought
column58: consult your general practitioner for some short-term pain relief. “It usually takes one to two weeks to recover
column59: ” said Dr Soh. “But for patients with poor core strength
column60: it can take up to six weeks for the pain to subside. In cases of an annular tear
column61: healing usually occurs naturally between six weeks and three months.” Yee added that if the pain is severe and lasts beyond four weeks
column62: you might want to check in with a specialist. “In rare situations
column63: consult a doctor early if there are symptoms of weakness in the legs
column64: or loss of control of the bladder or bowel

column1: No extra restrictions on import of face masks
column2: hand sanitisers; usual GST rules apply: Customs=17 Feb 2020 04:19PM (Updated: 17 Feb 2020 04:20PM)=CNA/hz(aj)=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid19-coronavirus-no-extra-restrictions-face-masks-gst-customs-12441830=" SINGAPORE: No extra restrictions have been imposed on face masks and hand sanitisers brought into Singapore
column3: the Singapore Customs said on Monday (Feb 17). "No additional Customs restrictions have been imposed on the import of face masks and hand sanitisers
column4: a spokesperson said in response to queries by CNA. As with all goods brought into Singapore
column5: travellers are required to declare and pay Goods and Services Tax (GST) if the total value of goods imported for personal use exceeds the GST import relief
column6: or the goods are for commercial purposes." The response comes after an image circulating on social media showed a sign put up by the Singapore Customs requesting that travellers who enter the country declare "all face masks and sanitisers"
column7: alongside other dutiable items such as tobacco
column8: cigarettes and alcohol.  The Customs spokesperson clarified that the sign depicted in the Facebook post was put up at the Singapore Cruise Centre in response to a "surge in the number of ferry passengers hand-carrying sizeable quantities of surgical masks and hand sanitisers into Singapore". "As a number of travellers had quantities of masks and sanitisers with values in excess of their GST import relief thresholds or which were for commercial purposes
column9: they were stopped at the baggage screening area and turned back to the Customs service counters for GST payment
column10: the spokesperson added. The sign was therefore put up with good intentions by our frontline staff to remind travellers to make their GST payments first before proceeding for customs clearance
column11: so as to minimise inconvenience and help expedite their clearance at the Singapore Cruise Centre. "Unfortunately
column12: the intent was misconstrued." The Customs spokesperson said that the sign was put up only at the cruise centre to address a specific situation
column13: and that the other checkpoints do not have similar signs. Singapore has seen a surge in demand for face masks amid concern over the novel coronavirus. Some retailers have raised the prices of masks drastically
column14: while private sellers have taken to selling boxes of face masks online
column15: usually in bulk. The authorities have repeatedly stressed that Singapore has sufficient masks in its stockpile
column16: and sent letters of demand asking several retailers to explain their pricing strategy for masks.  Download our app or subscribe to our Telegram channel for the latest updates on the coronavirus outbreak: https://cna.asia/telegram"
